Notes: Dark ruby-colored with purple nuances, this compressed, tightly-knit, austere Cabernet Sauvignon offers up straightforward aromas of black currant fruit, loamy earth, and new oak. Firm, with high tannin, medium body, and moderate concentration, it requires cellaring. Will it ever shed enough tannin to become harmonious? It is a gamble. Anticipated maturity: 2002-2012?

There is a lot going on in this wine in terms of a velvety texture, excellent concentration, and a saturatedruby/purple color. However, the overlay of new oak is excessive, and the wine has an international style rather than one that could be quickly identified as a Pomerol. Nevertheless, it is cleanly made and very good, if somewhat oaky. Anticipated maturity: 2003-2012.

Wine: Rangen de Thann Clos St. Urbain Vendage Tardive
Notes: RP: The extraordinary 1998 Pinot Gris Ranged de Thann Clos St. Urbain Vendage Tardive has a mouth-watering nose of candied blood oranges lightly dusted with botrytis-caused spiciness. Creamed red, yellow, and white fruits are interspersed with earth, minerals, and gravel in this complex, concentrated, bull-bodied behemoth. Its massive personality is well-buttressed by its superb acidity. Additionally, this muscular yet graceful wine has an unbelievably long finish. Anticipated maturity: 2005-2025."

WS:"Wonderfully fragrant and impressively ripe. What Châteauneuf is all about--plenty of wet earth, mineral, plum, sweet tannins and sweet fruit. A cascade of pleasure, full-bodied and long on the sparkling finish. Drink now through 2015."  RP: "One of the most powerful, concentrated 1999 Chateauneuf du Papes was produced at Chateau Pegau. The dense ruby/purple-colored 1999 Chateauneuf du Pape Cuvee Reservee boasts a powerful bouquet of pepper, garrigue, black fruits, and earth. Full-bodied and expansive, with sweet tannin giving it a more open-knit, accessible style than most young vintages of Pegau, this is a wine to drink while waiting for the 1998 and 1995 to become fully mature. Like all of this estates red wines, it was bottled with neither fining nor filtration."

Wine: Walter Clore Private Reserve Columbia Valley

Notes: RP: "The 1999 releases continue to push quality to extraordinary heights. Rivettis blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Nebbiolo, the 1999 Pin Monferrarto Rosso, is an exotic, ripe, luxuriously intense effort displaying extravagant flavors that border on excess. It is voluptuously-textured with intense aromas of red and black fruits, smoke, and new oak. While there is a tendency to think of this as an internationally-styled offering, Nebbiolo gives the wine a finesse and complexity not found in most new breed wines. Its texture, richness, and thickness are a total turn-on. Who knows how it will age, but certainly it is impossible to resist at present. My instincts suggest drinking it over the next 7-8 years, but it may be uncommonly long-lived."

RP: "The 1998 The Dead Arm Shiraz (from a vineyard planted prior to 1890) is outrageously rich, spectacular stuff, the likes of which only Australia seems capable of making. Whiners may complain that it is too big, too rich, too flavorful, and too damn good, but this opaque purple-colored offering is loaded with blackberry liqueur, smoke, charcoal, pepper, cassis, and licorice. Unctuously-textured and full-bodied, but neither heavy nor overbearing, the wine's sweet tannin and low acidity are hidden in the cascade of fruit and glycerin that melt on the palate. This riveting, compelling effort can be drunk now, but promises to age well for two decades or more."
Could be extemely long lived, but drinking very well already.

Notes: The modern-styled, expensive, but terrific 2001 Torre Muga is an unfiltered blend of 75% Tempranillo, 15% Mazuelo, and 10% Graciano. It is a wine of admirable intensity, full body, and superb purity, size, potency, and harmony. Give it another 1-3 years of bottle age and consume it over the following 12-15.

Web:  Franciscan Cabernet Sauvignon is a quintessential Napa Valley Cabernet. The 2001 vintage was marked by a roller coaster of weather changes, including frost in the early part of the growing season followed by cool and hot periods. Despite the unusual weather pattern, the end of the season provided the ideal combination of cool evenings and warm to cool days. This allowed for slow, even ripening that lets tannins, sugars and flavors to develop in unison. The result of this long hang time is a wine with supple tannins, complexity, intense flavors and overall balance.
forbes house tasting

Chandon Blanc de Noirs is characteristically a delicate salmon color. Dark cherry, currant and strawberry dominate both aroma and flavor with hints of cassis and blackberry. These red fruit flavors build in the mid-palate and finish with a soft, lingering, creamy texture.

Tiny bubbles elevate a complex bouquet of ripe pear, toasted brioche and apple compote. Lemon custard flavors caress the palate followed by notes of baked apple crisp and roasted hazelnuts. The elegant structure persists throughout the long, savory finish.

Unlike most sparkling wines, this cuvée begins with Pinot Noir and Zinfandel still wines that have been fermented on the skins, providing the flavor and body of a still wine. It then undergoes second fermentation in the bottle, so possesses the refreshing characters of a sparkling wine. Chandon Sparking Red excites the palate with rich and concentrated flavors of black cherry, sweet cranberry with hints of juniper berry and nutmeg.

A complex sparkling wine created in a robust style that offers weight and dimension to the palate. With extended time on the yeast, this wine has a creamy texture, combining aromas of toasted hazelnuts with notes of black cherry, baked apple and ginger.

n the glass, the color is a dramatic deep pink with a blush of sunset. Intense ripe strawberry, juicy watermelon, and fresh red cherry fruit aromas and flavors are interwoven with apple, pear, and stone fruit. On the palate, the wine is creamy and seductive, with defined structure from the addition of still Pinot Noir at triage. The overall impression is one of bold vibrancy and impact from start to finish.

a small amount of red wine (Pinot Noir) prior to tirage to create the distinctive salmon color with copper hues. The wines aromas are rich and complex - floral notes with Santa Rosa plum, raspberry and nutmeg. These aromas follow through on the palate and are layered with candied ginger and pomegranate flavors, evolving into truffle, cocoa and earthy tones. The wine finishes with excellent length and richness that will stand up to a variety of foods.

offers a combination of intriguing aromas; honey, fuji apple, poached pear, malt, toasted hazelnuts and dried flowers. Similar flavors of honey, pear, custard and lemon tart persist over the creamy, rich palate

A complex sparkling wine created in Chandons Reserve style, having been aged for three years on the lees, this Club Cuvée offers a delightfully appealing creamy texture. Bright fruit flavors of Fuji apple and baked pear are supported by notes of toasted hazelnut leading to a crisp, refreshing finish. This cuvée is the second in a series of three wines that will be released in three subsequent years, highlighting the transition from primary fruit flavors towards more complex, nutty characters. With four years on the lees, this wine is dominated by vibrant fruit flavors and aromas, with subtle hints of freshly baked bread.

wine is richly textured and deeply colored. It offers appealing baked apple aromas with toasted hazelnut and dulce de leche notes that are carried through the palate by a soft and silky mousse. The late-disgorged portion from Chandons reserve library contributes to the rich texture and deep, inviting golden color with layers of complexity. Like a well made garment, the structure is solid with many facets. The fresh, vibrant flavors persist along the weighty palate, joined by baked pear, quince and brioche that lead to Chandons characteristic soft, dry finish. An accent of bright, crisp acidity suggests great craftsmanship and high quality that both offers and celebrates great taste.

During the Renaissance, the Dukes of Burgundy claimed these vineyards and cellars for themselves, the best of which are to-day part of the vast Drouhin family estate. This superb white wine comes from the estate of the Marquis de Laguiche, the largest owner of Le Montrachet. Since 1947, Maison Joseph Drouhin has the entire charge of the estate, from the cultivation of the vineyards to the vinification of these two famous wines and their distribution around the world. The grapes are picked by hand in small crates, then carefully brought to Joseph Drouhin Winery in Beaune. After a slow and gentle pressing, the juice ferments in 228-liter oak barrels. The percentage of new oak varies, never exceeding 40%. Chassagne-Montrachet Marquis de Laguiche has a lovely gold green color. The nose is elegant, with pear, vanilla and apple as the dominant flavors. The wine is well balanced and round with a nice fruity finish. Very long and complex, this is a superb example of a great Chardonnay from Burgundy.

Grape Tray: A beautiful Champagne. Complex and elegant, evoking ginger, jasmine, citrus and honey aromas and flavors, accented by a biscuit and grain component coming as much from barrel fermentation as yeast aging. Very firmly structured and long. Enjoy with Asian foods or Parmesan cheese. 9,500 cases imported.

Directly North of Beaune, Chorey is a tiny village surrounded by Savigny-les-Beaune, Aloxe-Corton and Ladoix. This small appellation mainly produces red wines, exclusively from Pinot Noir. The soil is made of clay and limestone. The wine is often sold under the more common appellation of Côte-de-Beaune Villages. Joseph Drouhin owns vineyards in Chorey.  As in the rest of his estate, the viticultural practices remain traditional : no weed killers are used, ploughing is the only method. At the time of harvest, the grapes are hand-picked and brought in small crates to the cellars in Beaune. They are partially destemmed. The juice ferments in small open wooden fermenters. The maceration lasts for 10 to 18 days, depending on the quality of the grapes. The new wine goes through malolactic fermentation in wood, then is racked off its lees. It ages for 15 to 18 months in oak barrels. Chorey is a light, supple, very moderately tannic wine. Its colour is of medium depth and its fine aroma is reminiscent of cherries and raspberries.  Chorey needs a fine but not sophisticated cuisine : roasted poultry, grilled meats and soft cheese such as Reblochon or Brie.  (Joseph Drouhin web site, September 2, 2006).  This is delicious, combining cherry, berry and currant notes with a juicy texture and overall harmonious profile. Lovely balance, with a lingering finish. Drink now through 2010. 500 cases imported. (Wine Spectator, May 31, 2006).  This very good value Pinot Noir would make an excellent partner for grilled game bird, such as pheasant, or roast chicken stuffed with fresh herbs and sausage meat. The aromas suggest violets, cherry, fresh cranberry, clove and a hint of underbrush. It is light- to medium-bodied and juicy with soft tannins for balance.(Vintages panel, Oct. 2005).
From heart of historical Beaune, France.  Burgundy Appellations.

Our Sauvignon Blanc bottlings are meant to showcase delicate but complex varietal character, with just a hint of toasty French oak serving as a complement, not the focus, of the wine. To preserve that delicate character, malolactic fermentation was prevented and, while the wine is on its lees during its time in the barrels, those lees have not been stirred. This wine was blended from the lots most expressive of ripe yet lively Sauvignon Blanc, tempered with a little rich Semillon, all from Juliana Vineyards.

Petit Verdot is rarely bottled as a varietal wine because of its intensity and tannins, serving in traditional Bordeaux blends to add color and structure.  This wine, made from fruit grown in St. Supéry's home vineyard in Rutherford, was so attractive to me that I decided to bottle a small amount.  Inky, deep and rich, with full tannins, the Petit Verdot was blended with a small amount of Cabernet Sauvignon to round out the finish.  Only 204 cases produced.
"Rich, Supple and complex, with ripe currant, black cherry, plum and mocha flavors that are beautifully focused , smooth and polished. Delicious aftertaste." 1275 Cases

Notes: The 2002 vintage of Fume Blanc is our first official estate grown, produced, and bottled Sauvignon Blanc. The grapes were harvested from our American Canyon vineyard, an area that is cool, windy, and ideal for growing Sauvignon Blanc. The 2002 growing season was excellent with grapes ripening evenly, enabling us to complete our picking in just four days. This superb wine is reflective of its clay loam soil which gives a mineral quality and firm structure. The cooler climatic conditions also add vibrancy and life. On the palate, this Fume Blanc is broad and voluminous. There is power, yet the wine is soft and seductive. As you sip it, you will notice intriguing flavors of passion fruit, citrus, melon and fig, all derived from the Musque clone of commitment and passion for Sauvignon Blanc is clearly shown in this estate grown offering.
Personal favorite
2005 Xmas Gifts from BEST

2003 marks the first vintage that our Cabernet Sauvignon is estate grown. By blending wine from our Yountville vineyard with small amounts from our Rutherford and Calistoga vineyards, which are all farmed organically, we create a complex Cabernet Sauvignon with a distinctive personality. The result is a dark, muscular wine with intriguing aromas of licorice, cedar and blackberries with a hint of earthy truffles. Wonderfully drinkable upon release, the wines firm tannin structure promises it will benefit from aging.

Pour celui qui recherche un vin de France, produit dun seul cépage et qui se marie bien avec les plats de viandes rouges grillées ou en sauce, avec les petits gibiers comme le lapin ou les cailles et un fromage comme le Curé Labelle, la réserve de HAUTE VILLE sera un bon choix. Venant du midi de la France, élaboré avec un des meilleurs cépage, la Syrah, ce vin qui nous présente une robe dun rubis profond est marqué par des arômes de fruits noirs comme la cerises et la mûre. Ajoutez au nez des notes épicées comme le poivre. À la dégustation, en plus de retrouver les odeurs du nez, vous allez goûter un vin qui a une belle attaque, de la vivacité, bien équilibré, de la matière et qui en milieu de bouche vous fait découvrir des fruits confits et un ensemble caramel-moka assez peu courant.  Accord gourmand : On le sert entre 14 et 16° sur les plats que nous avons cités plus haut mais il se plait bien en compagnie de pâtes à la sauce tomates, de viandes sur le barbecue ou avec des saucisses bien rôties.  (http://tva.canoe.com, May 19, 2004).

Chateau Pesquié Côtes du Ventoux is a blend of 60% Grenache, 40% Syrah. It is a deep ruby-purple in color with a gorgeous nose of cassis, garrigues, blackberry and spices. Dry with moderate acidity and soft tannins, it is a full-bodied red with intense flavors of cassis, blackberries, coffee and licorice. With wonderful aromas, intense fruit, richness and complexity, this wine shows off the depth of quality in this terrific vintage for the Rhône.

The wines were fermented in small wood bins, hand punched during fermentation and pressed with a small basket press. The wines were aged separately. Towards the end of cellar aging, the wines were blended to create a unique wine consisting of 32% Dolcetto, 34% Nebbiolo and 34% Refosco. Nearly two additional years of bottle age has created a uniquely complex wine of elegance and structure.

The name Monsanto (meaning holy place) is taken from the medieval village where the cellar is situated. The property was established in 1750 and purchased by the Bianchi family in 1961. Though its history has always been important to them, the Bianchi family does not live in the past. Aldo Bianchi immediately created vineyards to match the type of Sangiovese he thought fit the place. His son Fabrizio has now stepped in to continue his fathers innovations. The 2008 Lincourt Sta. Rita Hills Pinot Noir is a blended wine from our meticulously maintained, estate vineyards within the Sta. Rita Hills AVA. This fruit was hand-harvested and sorted in the vineyard prior to arrival at the winery. The clusters were then carefully destemmed to keep the berries intact. Jack stems were removed before the fruit was transferred to small, stainless steel, open-top fermenters. The must (juice and skins) underwent a coldsoak for four days prior to inoculation with cultured yeast and was then gently punched down for 14-24 days. After primary (alcoholic) fermentation was complete, the new wine was drained and the skins were gently pressed. These two fractions were then settled separately and introduced to barrels.

It demonstrates intriguing and inviting notes of smoked bacon, white and black cracked pepper and wet forest floor on the nose. On the palate, it is exuberant with ripe notes of minerality, ripe boysenberries and earthy mushrooms. This is the last wine from our best block of estate Chardonnay grapes. The 27-year-old vines were pulled out after the 1999 harvest and the block has since been replanted with Pinot Noir. The block showed its best for its last year. Flavors of crisp ripe apples, toasted hazelnuts, and fresh figs meld into a creaminess that is integrated and balanced.The wine went through fermentation, stirring of the lees, a long, slow, 100% malolactic fermentation and the aging process all in small French oak barrels.

After four days of air, this wineâs aromatics sweetened further, displaying jammy blackberry and blueberry scents. Bold, full-bodied, and expansive, the Graham benefited the most from extensive contact with air of all the 2003s tasted for this report. This opulently jammy wine assaults the palate with powerful yet soft layers of oily, candied red fruits as well as notes of tar and hints of mocha. A highly concentrated effort, it is creamy textured, suave, and reveals an admirably long finish filled with additional layers of dark fruits intermingled with spices. Projected maturity: 2030-2055." RP 90. A gorgeous tank-fermented and aged Spanish red, Panarrozs deep ruby/purple-colored 2003 is a super value from Jumilla. A blend of equal parts Syrah, Mourvedre, and Grenache, it boasts a deep ruby/purple color to the rim as well as a rich perfume of pen ink, graphite, blackberries, and currants. Consume this medium-bodied, nicely textured, plump, juicy 2003 over the next 1-2 years.

RP 87. A custom blend put together by importer Dan Kravitz, the 2003 Arcs is a Spanish version of a French Cotes du Rhone. Notes of pepper, black cherries, and kirsch are presented in an elegant, crisp, medium-bodied, fruity format. This tank-fermented and aged, fruity blend of 88% Grenache and 12% Tempranillo is meant to be consumed over the next 12-18 months. It can even be served chilled. Buy it by the trunkful!

Region: France Vin de Pays dOc, Costieres et Soleil
Notes: I needed a basic table wine to go with a pork loin with rosemary and sundried tomatoes. You know, something basic, nothing grand or full of itself. I saw this Plume Bleue that is a Vin de Pays dOcthats usually as basic as a wine gets. It comes from the Costieres et Soleil which is a sub-region of Costieres de Nimes, in other words, a red table wine from the south Rhone Valley. But there is more background to this wine than I presupposed. First, before I go any farther, this wine is a good value and better than a basic table wine. Dark and sinister in color, this little Plume Bleue had lovely and rich aromas of plums with wild herbs and earthy musk. Medium-bodied with a vigorous palate, a little chewy, a fruit forward character, with a smoky and mellow finish. This is a wine to be gulped rather than sipped and it made my pork loin shine, brighter than I daresay it was. Now, regarding the wines background, it is a 50-50 blend of Syrah and Grenache from Mark Finchams vineyards in Costieres de Nimes. Mark happens to be the husband of Laurence Feraud (Yes, a woman star winemaker) of Domaine du Pegau which is one of the top Chateauneuf-du-Pape estates with its wine sometimes categorized as cult. Their Plume Bleue has been produced and targeted towards a U.S. export market seeking high quality table wines at a valued price. This fits the bill nicely. Note also this wine is sold as Pegovino in Europe which doesnt resonate on American ears as well as Plume Bleue. The palate is the same however. Bon.

"Readers looking for an Italian version of Chateauneuf du Pape should check out the 2004 Costera. Made from the Sardinian clone of Grenache called Cannonau, Carignan and Bovale Sardo, it is a chunky, robust, meaty effort revealing scents of garrigue, kirsch liqueur, white chocolate, pepper and spice. Full-bodied, with terrific fruit as well as loads of personality, it should be enjoyed over the next several years." Made from 90% Cannonau, 5% Carignano and 5% Bovale Sardo grown in the Costera vineyard. The wine is aged in French barriques for 6-8 months prior to bottling. The intense, ruby red color tends toward orange with age. The full bouquet displays typical varietal character. Warm and full bodied on the palate with excellent texture, ripe fruit flavors and pleasant tannins.

Wine: Alta Valle della Greve Il Carbonaione
Notes: Big and rich red, with loads of dark berry, spice and meaty aromas and flavors. Full-bodied and chewy, with compacted fruit and loads of flavor on the finish. Full-throttle red. Sangiovese. Best after 2004. 3,500 cases made.
Leonardo Locascio selection
Beautifully crafted, with ripe plum, berry and light coffee aromas. Medium- to full-bodied, with well-integrated tannins and a long finish. Drink now.
Old Doc's:

Robert Parker-92 "Prunotto's 1996 Barolo Bussia is a spectacular, full-bodied, rich wine displaying scents of rose petals, tobacco, black fruits, cedar, and toasty French oak. Ripe, moderately tannic, dense, and chewy, it requires 2-3 years of cellaring, and should evolve easily for 15-20 years."

compelling...undoubtedly the super-star of this area... gorgeous aromas of blackberries, cassis, espresso, chocolate, and a touch of smoke...fabulous concentration, full body, great precision as well as purity...Displaying an overall elegance and gracefulness despite its depth and richness...prodigious effort. Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. Best after 2004
Leonardo Locascio selection
Plenty of Merlot character, with plum, blackberry and olive. Full-bodied, with silky tannins and lots of flavor. Best after 2004. 2,000 cases made. (JS)
A full-bodied red, with rich berry and oak on the nose. Firm and vibrant palate, with lots of firm tannins and a robust finish with good clean fruit. Best after 2005. 6,000 cases made. JS

Wine: Vigna del Fattore Vino Nobile di Montepulciano
Notes: Lovely nose of flowers, berries and light coffee. Medium-bodied, with light and soft tannins and a fruity finish. Delicious. Drink now through 2007. 5,000 cases made. (JS)
70% Cab Sauv 30% Cab Franc
wedding gift from Laura#2

ST: Blackish garnet, slightly lighter at the edge. Quite spicy on the nose, along with very ripe plum. Rich in extract and velvety in texture; the plummy fruit is ripe and fresh. Long, tarry finish shows a silky, elegant texture and benefits from enlivening acidity. Quite forward compared to the earliest, slow-maturing vintages of this wine such as the 1985 and 1990-partly a result of the vintage, but partly due, I believe, to a new philosophy in the cellar.
Typical for NZ:  very fruity nose with tons of grapefruit and nectarine

Wine: Folie A Deux Muscat A Deux

Notes: Dried berry, plum, mustard seed and vanilla flavors finish with earthy and firm tannins. Drink now through 2004. 2,073 cases made.
1683 cases produced.

Notes: Wine Library -- Think there is no value in California Zin? You must try this one! For only $8, you get the classic jammy fruit with a hint of spice. Clean and never fake tasting, this is the perfect everyday drinker or BBQ wine."
Rauser Ranch Lodi 90 year old vines

Crisp and linear, this shows a narrower range of lime, apple and mineral flavors, but stays true to the kabinett style. Vibrant and tangy, with a lingering, lime-tinged aftertaste.  500 cases imported

There's a spicy, tangy quality to this white, along with quince and anise. It's all underscored by a mineral element and a vibrant structure, with a fine, lingering aftertaste of stone and anise.  3,000 cases made

Notes of blueberries, wild flowers, black cherries, and background subtle wood emerge from this medium-bodied, fruit-driven effort. With silky tannin, excellent purity, and a real personality, enjoy over the next several years." Robert Parker
Floral, crushed berry, currant and black cherry aromas are tight, concentrated and focused, and the flavors come through in the same way on the palate.  1,440 cases made
75% Merlot, 25% Cabernet Sauvignon
TRADER JOES

Barrel Tasting: Mineral, licorice and asphalt, with plenty of fruit.  Full-bodied, with supersilky tannins and a long finish.  Very pretty wine.  Plenty of cab character. 90 points JS/WS 2010. Released 2/19/11
Light-bodied, with modest straw and chive flavors, followed by a soft finish. 2,000 cases imported

"Indigenous grape varietals are playing more important roles in the world's wines (despite the falsehoods promoted in the disingenuous movie, Mondovino), and the 2003 Aglianico Contado IGT is fashioned from 100% Aglianico that has been reclaimed by Riccardo Cotarella. It is a stunning Italian red. Notes of crushed rocks, acacia flowers, almond paste, blackberries, and currants jump from the glass of this opaque ruby/purple-colored offering. Boasting fabulous intensity, medium to full body, beautiful purity, and nicely integrated acidity, wood, and tannin, it was aged in both large neutral oak ovals and smaller barrels. This wine represents incredible value for the money."#2; COLOR-really nice; NOSE-red beets, hint or Kirsch, potpourri of flowers; TASTE-a great shock of acidity on mid-palate, interesting layers of green, red & yellow peppers, this is real wine, shoots w/ a chocolate covered strawberries reduction sauce on the finish (keeps New World fans on board), nice smokiness; a SCREAMING value for $12; RP-91; GV-90-
FRUIT WINE FORTIFIED 16%
55% Merlot, 27% Cabernet Sauvignon, 8% Cabernet Franc
mix of complex fruit aromas soft tannins and rich palate.
Save for Special occasion
Medium to full bodied white, golden in color, hints of smoke/spice
Blended with a small percentage of Petit Sirah, full bodied w/excellent balance.

There are 15,000 cases of the 1999 Insignia, a blend of 71% Cabernet Sauvignon, 21% Merlot, 6% Petit Verdot, 1% Cabernet Franc, and 1% Malbec. The core of this offering tends to come from Rutherford-grown fruit. The saturated dense purple-colored 1999 offers a tight but promising nose of incense, spice box, black fruits, and vanilla. This elegant, stylish, and medium to full-bodied offering is made in a more French-like, finesse style than such blockbusters as 1997, 1996, 1995, and 1994. Give it 3-4 years of cellaring and consume it over the following 15-18.
Highly Recommended, Hard to get
Powerful, dry wine, with flinty mineral notes and a long finish
Bouquet of spicy flavour reminiscent of wild herbs, with fruity overtones, powerful and full-bodied on the palate.
purchased in UK

Medium-deep red-ruby. Roasted, tarry red fruits, animal fur and chocolate on the nose; as vibrant and vinous as a barrel sample. Extremely lush and concentrated, and already highly aromatic in the mouth, with notes of red and black fruits, roasted nuts, spices, chocolate and tobacco. Beautifully integrated acidity. Finishes very long, with substantial, very fine tannins. A superb vintage for this top Hermitage bottling.

The 2000 Vacqueyras exhibits classic Provencal characteristics of lavender, thyme, and rosemary intertwined with kirsch and currants. Fat, opulent, medium to full-bodied, and peppery, this gorgeous Vacqueyras may merit an outstanding score. Drink it over the next 4-5 years. Score - 88. (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com, Dec. 2001)  Food match: grilled gourmet sausage.  (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).
Riesling / Gewurztraminer Blend
deep rich and intense with layers of concentrated fruit

Tones of mid-ruby. A nose of cinnamon, cherry and raspberry preserve, with a slightly floral element. Medium-bodied, with a flattering personality, this finishes medium-long with a pleasing aftertaste.
Purchased in Paris, France

Wine: Le Dit de La Clapassiere Seguret

Winery: La Cave des Vignobles de Gigondas
Notes: Basically, it's hard to go wrong in the Rhône Valley with the 2000 vintage ... In the south, I give 2000 an overall rating of 93 points, or outstanding, on the Wine Spectator 100-point scale. Many winemakers had billed the vintage as being close to the quality of the classic-rated '98 (95 points), and it doesn't miss by far, being a marriage between the powerful '98 and the elegant '99 (87 points). Where yields were kept in check, the '00s have plenty of substance, even though they come across as more subtle than the blockbuster '98s. (Per-Henrik Mansson, www.winespectator.com, Feb. 3, 2003)
intense red fruit and spice

"Spécialiste des Crémants de Bourgogne, Jean-François Delorme n'en néglige pas pour autant ses appellations tranquilles. Ce Varot en témoigne. Jaune paille et brillant, il suggère le pamplemousse et la noisette dans un accord heureux. Légèrement citronné par la suite, il garde de la fraîcheur tout en développant une solide structure. Il sera intéressant de le goûter en magnum d'ici quelques années.  (Source:  Guide Hachette 2004,
full and fruity with long smooth finish

Medium ruby purple colour; dry and medium bodied with aromas and flavours of blackberry and cassis; soft tannins, ripe fruit and some finish.  Serving suggestion:  veal or mild red meat dishes and soft chesses.  (Source:  LCBO web site, May 2003)
Deep ruby color. Aroma of red berries, tobacco and vanilla.  Smooth and harmonious.

Wine: Cabernet Sauvignon vin de Pays D'Oc

Varietal: Merlot noir (44%), Cabernet-Sauvignon (33%), Cabernet Franc (20%), Petit Verdot (3%)

Notes: The Alsatian version of this grape is more generous in bouquet and flavour than the Italian. This has peas and green apple on the nose. The palate is balanced and pleasant with a light zing and enough of everything to suit seafood with a mild oriental spice component. What about scallops with a lemon grass, coconut and cream reduction, maybe some lime leaf tinges?  (Source:  www.winereviews.ca, March 2003).  Comment on winery:  Ancient top-class family wine house at Riquewihr, Alsace.  (Source:  Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book 2003).
11%  Label states good for Raclette & Fondue

Schlumberger, the largest family-owned winery in the Alsace, produces this Gewurz in an intriguing off-dry style. Previous VINTAGES have consistently displayed pretty lychee, peach and nutmeg. The wine complement s beautifully dishes such as chicken vindaloo or seafood stir-fries.  (Source:  Vintages web site, July 2003).
A soft, sweet, dessert-style Champagne with flavors of pear, vanilla and almond on the finish. Enjoy as an aperitif or with cheeses and appetizers.
Fresh, fruity and subtle in style, a rose champagne with aromas of redcurrants and wild strawberries.
