Winery: Les Maitres Vignerons De La Presqu'ile De Saint-tropez

Notes: Our panel's tasting note: Medium ruddy colour with aromas of baked clay, bittersweet chocolate and figs. Dry with ripe tannins and well-integrated fruit. Medium-bodied with a medium long finish. Food match: herb-crusted lamb.  (Source:  Vintages - Dec. 2001)  Very floral, with violets, roses and hints of fruit. Medium-bodied, with well-integrated tannins and a medium aftertaste. Needs some time to come together. Try after 1999. (Source:  Wine Spectator - 1998)

Our panel's tasting note: Medium deep ruby colour with aromas of sun-warmed berries, mineral, underbrush, red currant and pepper. Dry, a bit rustic, but very food friendly. Supple, medium full-bodied with a lingering finish. Food match: portobello mushroom burgers, roasted vegetables  (Source:  Vintages, May 2003).

Made mostly with Cabernet Sauvignon, grown on gravelly soil, Pontet-Chappaz may not be as well-known as some of the more famous Margaux houses, but they have a reputation of taking extreme care with the fruit, resulting in high quality wines.  (Source:  November 1, 2003).

Wine: Chateau Haut Bages Libéra - Granc Cru Classe

Notes: elegant nose and a smooth blackcurrant palate

Wine: La Terrasse de la Garde pessac-léognan

Notes: Merlot 90% + Cab Sauv 10%

Tasting note: Shy in aroma, but no shortage of apricot and peach flavors in this rich, vibrant Pinot Gris. Medium-bodied, with lip-smacking acidity, making it delicious on its own. Drink now. Score - 87. (Bruce Sanderson, www.winespectator.com, Nov. 30, 2002)  Food match: apéritif, Cantonese-style chicken stir-fry or vegetarian finger foods.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).
A soft, lush white, featuring floral, tropical fruit and citrus notes on an open, fleshy frame. Drink now. 11,900 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, November 30, 2002)

Mommessin Beaujolais 2002 ($10.60, No. 313734) is Beaujolais as it was meant to be: light, bright and brimming with fruit.  On hot summer days (remember those?), the French turn to one wine when they want a refreshing red: Beaujolais.   Assuming some parts of Canada will see some hot weather before the season ends, a terrific value to look for is Mommessin Beaujolais 2002 ($10.60, No. 313734). This is basic Beaujolais as it was meant to be: light, bright and brimming with focused cherry-like fruit and brisk but not overwhelming acidity. If wines were emotions, this one would be happy, and it would bring much cheer to any backyard gathering.

Wine: Baron de Hoen, Pinot Blanc, Vin d'Alsace

Notes: Established in 1824 by Eugène Klipfel, his decendants continue to operate the winery to this day. They own 100 acres (40 ha) of vineyards, of which 37 acres (15 ha) produce the Grand Cru wines, including this Riesling Kastelberg.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw colour with aromas of petrol, floral and mineral. Dry, softening, very attractive wine with a medium body and lingering finish. Food match: lightly spiced Asian seafood dishes. (Source:  Vintages - October 5, 2002 Release).

Very distinctive with its green olive and Provençal herbs character. Packed with lime, apple, and with a touch of toasted hazelnut. It's medium-bodied, firm and almost tannic, but also satisfying. Best from 2002 through 2006. (PM)

Region: France - Burgundy - Côte de Beaune - Puligny-Montrachet

Notes: Open-textured, this is a bit gritty with tannins, but it's generous with its meat and blackberry flavors, finishing on a savory note. Shiraz, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot.  115,000 cases made

Region: France - Bordeaux - Premières Côtes de Blaye
Notes: This is a very typical Bordeaux at a reasonable price. Plum, cassis, cedar and tea bag are met by lively acidity and a bit of tannin. Medium intensity, concentration and length with fruit and tea flavours lingering. Drinking nicely now at nearly five years of age but could be held for 3-4 more. (Jefferson Davis, Wine Access, First In Line E-Report, April 2003)
Purchased in Paris, France

Our panel's tasting note: Electric pink colour with aromas of lilac and cherry. Dry, fine aroma replays with a good fullness surrounded by crisp acid. Light to medium-bodied with a medium finish. (Sept. 2002)  Food match: steamed clams.  (Source:  July 2003).
bom
Purchased in Paris, France
Prix: Argent (Aquitaine) et Or (Blaye-Bourg 08) + 2 étoiles Hachette 09

Not surprisingly, this estate's owner, the Rothschild family (who also owns Lafite-Rothschild), has been making significant investments in Duhart's winemaking facilities and vineyards. These investments helped create a blockbuster 2003 and 2005 as well as an outstanding 2006. Eliminating 50% of the crop produced a 1986-ish blend of 70% Cabernet Sauvignon and 30% Merlot exhibiting notes of creme de cassis, pain grille, black cherries, and undertones of loamy earth, herbs, and spice. Copious richness and up-front fruit (the latter a characteristic of the vintage) along with good freshness and liveliness suggest this Pauillac will be at its finest between 2012-2025. Score - 91-93. (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com)
Grenache (50%), Shiraz (40%), Mourvedre (10%)

Imagine the smell of recently cut hay next to an orchard of nectarines on an early spring morning. Somehow, some anise is in the air too. Lemon, mango and apple flavours are in harmony on the palate. A wine like this makes for lively conversation about any topic.  (Source:  www.winereviews.ca, March 2003).
A bit lean, but good berry and cherry character, light body and fresh finish.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, Barrel Tasting, June 2001)

The complex set of aromas includes apricot, lemon zest, pear, mineral, oak and a hint of butter. This dry, youthful wine is good now and will become very impressive with a few years of maturation (2-4 years). This long finishing wine will work nicely with grilled trout or chicken kiev. (Vintages panel, March 2006)

Refined wine. Raspberry and perfumed character on the nose. Medium-bodied, with well-integrated tannins and a fruity aftertaste. Very well made. Best from 2000 through 2004.   (Source:  Wine Spectator, September 15, 1998).
blackberry, bramble fruits

Those searching for a low-cost Chablis-styled white on the general list are well advised to check out Bouchard Pere et Fils 2001 Macon-Lugny Saint Pierre at $12.95. Originating in the Maconnais, which is most famous for Pouilly-Fuisse, it is bordered in the south by Beaujolais and Burgundy to the north. In terms of flavours, this gutsy 13% alcohol effort more resembles a higher-priced Chablis. Indeed, at one tasting session it blew away a somewhat tart Bichot 2001 Petit Chablis at $17.95.   (Source:  Michael Vaughan, National Post, December 7, 2002).

Pale straw colour; Light nutty, citrus, flinty/mineral nose with yeasty notes; Dry, medium bodied, with fresh fruit, vanilla and melon flavours with a long finish.  Serving Suggestion:  Shellfish; Chicken; Pasta in cream sauce; Sushi; White fish.  (Source: LCBO web site, July 2004).
got 15+10% off, so real cost is around 16.00

Pale to medium straw colour with aromas of honey, apple and mineral. Both varietal characters show through nicely. Dry with good aroma replays. Medium-bodied with a lingering finish. Tasted in October 2002.  Food match: grilled squid.(Source:  Vintages, May 10, 2003).  The good French value is Château de Montguéret Saumur 2001 ($13.90, No. 933010), a blend of 80 per cent chenin blanc and 20 per cent chardonnay, light and fresh, with hints of citrus and honeydew.  (Source:  Globe and Mail, Beppi Crosariol, May 10, 2003).

Lovely aromas of strawberries and roses. Medium-bodied, with a solid core of ripe fruit and very refined tannins. Long finish. Second wine of Dauzac. Best after 2005. 6,665 cases made. (Wine Spectator web site, January 9, 2004).  Deep ruby colour with aromas reminscent of blackberry, cherry, cedar and chocolate. It is dry, supple and well-balanced. Medium-bodied, long finishing, it will reward 4+ years in a cellar. (Vintages, December 4, 2004).
aromas of honeyed citrus tropical hints steely finish

Wine: Chateauneuf du Pape - Dom Vieux Lazaret Cuvee Exceptionelle
Notes: R Parker (Wine Advocate):  "The 2005 Chateauneuf du Pape Cuvee Exceptionnelle has turned out to be significantly better than I thought last year when I tasted it prior to bottling. The greatest wine Quiot has ever made in my opinion, this wine shows a dense ruby/purple color and a gorgeous nose of camphor, blackberry, kirsch, some roast beef and Provencal herbs. Full-bodied with great intensity, beautiful purity, a multi-dimensional mouthfeel, and a spectacular finish of close to a minute, this is a fabulous effort from Quiot and should drink well for close to two decades."  //  WSpec: "Has a solid core of blackberry, melted licorice and coffee flavors, with hints of briar and currant paste on the mineral- and earth-driven finish. There's solid, latent grip. This fleshes out as it airs. Best from 2010 through 2020. 2,000 cases made. " 90 points

Tasting note: Richer and more succulent than their Mercurey Les Mauvarennes. Good grip. Good substance. Ripe and fragrant. Long and satisfying. Even better than the Mauvarennes. From 2007. (Clive Coates, MW, The Vine, Jan. 2004)  (Source:  Vintages, Sep 3, 2005).

Buttered toast and spices make up the aromatic profile of the 2002 Saint-Aubin La Chateniere. Medium- to full-bodied, it displays excellent richness, a broad medium to full-bodied, silky personality, and copious flavors of smoked minerals. It should be drunk over the next 4 years. Score - 88 (Pierre Rovani, www.erobertparker.com, Aug. 2004)

This oaked Chardonnay is medium yellow-gold in colour with aromas of citrus, apricot, dried herbs and toast. It is a vibrant, medium-bodied, crisp wine with a good balance and lingering finish. Enjoy with grilled salmon.(Claudius Fehr, Vintages, Nov. 2005)  Dark cherry and blackberry notes prevail in this rich, supple red. More modern in style, achieving density at the expense of detail. Very tasty nonetheless. Drink now through 2010. 1,000 cases made.  (Wine Spectator, Oct 15, 2006).

Region: France - Burgundy - Côte D'Or - Savigny Les Baune
Notes: Romance and wine have always gone together, but romance and vines are a unique variation. Vincent Sauvestre and his wife, Aleth, consider their Savigny-lès-Beaune vineyard to be a very special place. Many years ago, Vincent went to Aleth?s father?s residence to discuss the purchase of vines to use in planting this very vineyard. As the story goes, Aleth answered the door and ? you can guess the rest. Their 2002 Savigny is a fresh, delicious approachable wine that does great justice to this story.  (Vintages, July 23, 2005).

The village of Santenay sits at the southern tip of the Côte d?Or in the heart of Burgundy. Expect pleasing aromas of apricots and warm croissants and ripe fruit flavours to burst on your tastebuds. A very good value for white Burgundy.  (Vintages, Sept. 16, 2006).
Wine Magazine, December 2002 (Page 71)

Château Latour 1997A vintage of equatorial weather, says Mr. Engerer, very hot and humid and somewhat diluted, though September contributed a bit to concentrate the grapes; he opposes the opinion that no 1997 wines were long-term agers saying that the Château Latour can still be cellared until at least 2005-2006.
Firm in texture, with a solid core of dark berry and currant flavors, shaded with smoky, slightly tarry notes that mingle through the cocoa-scented finish.  5,625 cases made.

Mid-ruby colour. Aromas of cherry cough drops and beets with floral, cranberry and leather notes. Great fruit concentration in this medium-bodied wine. Fruit forward but will gain complexity over the next 2-3 years. The wine has a lingering, satisfying finish. (Vintages panel, March 13, 2006)

Our panel's tasting note: Medium ruby colour with aromas of spice, olive, mushroom, plum and raspberry. Dry, medium-bodied, velvety red wine with a solid fruit-driven finish. Food match: beef stir-fry with hoisin sauce. (Source:  Vintages - August 2002 release)
Decanter Gold - intense red berry rich and silky smooth complex

From vines that are 30+ years old, the blend is mostly Syrah with Grenache in a supporting role.  Our panel's tasting note: A jammy wine with aromas of raspberry, strawberry, cherry and chocolate. Dry, full-bodied, concentrated but kept in balance by supple tannins. A robust red for robust red meats or pasta sauces. (Vintages - Sept. 10, 2001)

Segond de Dufort is the second wine of second growth, Durfort-Vivens. Second wines are great alternatives to the 'grand vin'. They require less ageing and cash layout. Under the ownership of Gonzague Lurton, this winery has undergone a renaissance since he took over in 1992. Look for the typical Margaux elegance. A good starter wine for those new to Bordeaux.

Jancis Robinson, on her website, described the 1998 vintage of this wine as combining "both fruitiness and classically understated claret structure ... a steal ... " (Wines of the Week, www.jancisrobinson.com, Dec. 22, 2000)  Our panel's tasting note: Black violet colour with aromas of gingerbread, plum skin and a touch of herbs. Dry, quite fleshy and approachable. Medium full-bodied with a lingering finish. Calls out for food. Food match: beef stew, steak off the grill, roast beef with Yorkshire pudding. (Source:  Vintages - August 2002 Release)
Merlot 40%, Cabernet Sauvignon 45%, Cabernet Franc 15%
Merlot 60%,Cabernet Sauvignon 29%, Cabernet Franc 11%

Tasting Note:  Pale straw colour; Subtle aromas of citrus and green apple; Dry, light bodied, with clean apple/lemon flavours, crisp acidity on finish.  Serving Suggestion:  Add cassis for a Kir; shellfish; light seafood dishes; ceviche.  (Source:  Vintages web site, April 24, 2005).

Toronto-born Peter Kjellberg is the owner/winemaker of Château les Cabannes, an exciting, up-and-coming St-Émilion property.  Tasting note: A supple, medium-bodied, Merlot-dominated wine with good depth of flavour. The aromas excite with a combination of chocolate, black cherry and new oak. Enjoy with braised beef or pulled pork dishes. (VINTAGES panel, Feb. 2005)
medium-bodied ripe smoky fruits

Region: Provence - Vin de pays de Var

Notes: Medium yellow gold colour with aromas of peach, pineapple, honey and golden raspberry. Medium in sweetness with excellent aroma replays. Medium full-bodied with a long finish. (Vintages, February 2003)

Probably more univerally known as Château Bel-Orme so as not be confused with Château Tronquoy-Lalande, this property is planted to 45% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Cabernet Franc, 3% Malbec and 2% Petit Verdot. In terrific years such as 2000, Bel-Orme is known for producing wines that are dense with rich aromas that suggest incense, sweet currants, cedar, leather, and spice box. This wine is drinking very well right now, but will reward 2-4 more years in a cellar. Enjoy with grilled lamb or roast beef au jus.
Purchased in Paris, France

note: Full ruby colour with aromas of mocha, cocoa bean, cassis and integrated oak tones. Dry, generous and accessible, it will also reward cellaring of 3-8 years. Full-bodied with a very long, vibrant finish. (VINTAGES panel, March 2004)

Alluring and intriguing aromatics of honeycomb and floral notes guide the taster into this full fruit, bone dry white. White peaches and nectarine flavours dominate the flavour profile while the texture is plush and round in this medium-bodied beauty. The finish is rich and portends a great future. One of those wines that you buy three; trying one in 3 years, the next in 6 and the last in ten. You will then be hooked on, and convinced of, the beauty of old Rieslings. (VH)

Sweet tangerines slightly honeyed bounce In the bouquet. This wine is dry with elegant lingering fruit. I see scallops in a Pernod sauce touched with sesame and lemon grass. Do not overcook the crustaceans please.  (Source:  www.winereviews.ca, March 2003).
elegant complex rich mineraly with a nutty toasty finish

The wine is certified organic by ECOCERT. Our Quality Assurance laboratory has determined that this wine contains 18 ppm of free sulphur. The winery is located near the beautiful walled medieval city of Carcassonne and has been producing wines with organic methods since 1986.  Food match: grilled salmon.  (Source:  Vintages, August 7, 2004).

Loads of mineral here. Pear and apple are the main fruit flavors, but the [i]terroir[n] shows through. It really resonates on the palate, with stone notes, and has a vivid structure. On the dry side and racy. Drink now through 2006. 500 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, June 30, 2002)
Long Storage
Purchased in Paris, France

A classic Médoc with aromas of cassis, tobacco and currant. In the mouth, it is beautifully structured and the fruit, acid and tannins are well-balanced. Medium to full-bodied with a long finish. Deserves 3+ years in a cellar to truly shine.(Vintages panel, Nov. 2005)

Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw colour with aromas of toast, sour apple and cinnamon. Dry, soft, round, medium-bodied Chardonnay with a very good finish. (Source:  Vintages - November 2002 Release)
purchased in Normandie during vacation

Chartron et Trébuchet have a well-earned reputation for producing elegant, flavourful white wines where the oak is used to enhance the flavours, not dominate them. This 100% Chardonnay Pernand-Vergelesses is a prime example of that philosophy in action.  (Vintages, August 5, 2005).

Gorgeous, silky and harmonious, offering orange blossom, honey and beeswax aromas and flavors. Lightweight, elegant and vibrant, it carries its sweetness with poise, ending with freshness and a long aftertaste of honey. Drink now through 2020. 1,250 cases made. (BS)
http://www.snooth.com/wine/chateau-dereszla-tokaji-aszu-5-puttonyos-2000/

Winery: Domaine de L'Abbaye du petit Quincy

Notes: This wine had already been bottled at the time of my visit. It reveals plenty of intense black currant fruit with a hint of chocolate. It will drink well for 3-4 years.

Vignobles Jestin produces this Monbazillac on just 3 ha from a blend of 80% Sémillon, 10% Sauvignon Blanc and 10% Muscadelle. This Monbazillac will work well with foie gras, blue-veined cheese or a lemon tart.  Our panels tasting note: Intense golden straw colour with aromas of honey, pineapple, raisin, peach and spice. Medium sweet, rich/intense and ripe. Medium full-bodied with a long, lush finish. (Oct. 2000)  (Source:  Vintages, February 2002).

"High-toned and floral, exuding rose, ginger and apple flavors matched to an elegant profile. The fine mousse ushers in a firm, mouthwatering finish. Drink now through 2009. 2,500 cases made. - BS" #1 (tie); NOSE-earthy, lemon grass, citrus, toastyness, hint of walnut, TASTE-very complex, lively on the finish, spritzy tropical flavor, baked bread, long finish, COMPLETELY DYNAMITE, WS-88; GV-92
Mat: Fisk eller lyst kjøtt med sjysaus, pizza, pasta.

The nettles, gooseberries and herbaceous aromas that float from the glass put one in mind of a racy Sauvignon Blanc. There is enough zingy acidity, passion fruit and fresh lime notes to carry the illusion through to the palate. One could be fooled in a blind tasting, and an even bigger fool for not giving this a try, with or without a chèvre-laced green salad. This is a winecurrent.com exceptional value pick. (VH)

The production [at Château d'Aquéria] is large, but the wine is among the finest of the appellation. It often carries 14% alcohol, and is known for its power and provocative display of red fruits, primarily cherries and strawberries. (Robert Parker Jr., Wines of the Rhône Valley, 1997)  Of the last vintage, David Lawrason (Wine Access, June 2002) said: It's full, rounded and elegant, with very good length.  Food match: black olive tapenade on grilled bread, poached sole with fresh herbs.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Due to its deep colour, Cahors red wine has for over a century been called the 'black wine'. Based upon the inky dark colour, this 2002 vintage definitely lives up to the reputation. It doesn't stop there, though, as the intense aromas of blackberry, cassis, cocoa bean and iodine, plus the concentrated, firm/grippy flavours confirm that this is a Malbec to reckon with. Give it at least three years in a cellar to be truly rewarded.  (VINTAGES panel, June 2005)

Our panel's tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of mineral and green apple. Dry, elegant, very fresh with a substantial length to the finish. Food match: phyllo pastry stuffed with asparagus or other spring/summer vegetables and shrimp.(Source:  Vintages - August 2002 Release)

Wine: Chateau Lenormand Premieres Cotes De Bordeaux

Notes: As Vin de Pays d'Oc covers the whole of the Midi, so Vin de Pays du Jardin de la France encompasses all the regions of the Loire; thus the grapes may come from anywhere within this region's borders. The producer tells us that the majority of grapes used in this wine are from the Touraine region of the Loire Valley.  Food match: lobster bisque.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Juicy Sauvignon, with grass, chive, fig and gooseberry notes that run through the bright, refreshing finish. Very tasty. New wine from Jolivet, in a markedly New World style. Drink now. (Wine Spectator, Oct. 15, 2002).
Mis en Bouteille Au Chateau
Syrah

And for those who like red even with light, summery, fish dishes, there's Trenel Chiroubles 2001 ($18.95, No. 712505), a serious Beaujolais with good extract and balance, ripe berry flavours and a crisp, long finish.  Pick of the week.  (Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 7, 2003).  The négociant Trenel produces an entire range of Beaujolais and Mâconnais wines; they also create Crème de Cassis and Crème de Framboise, both of which have been featured at Vintages in the past.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium ruby colour with aromas of strawberry, blueberry and clove. Dry, lively and ripe. Light-bodied with a very good finish. (Oct. 2002)  Food match: pork loin, grilled snapper fillets.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Comments on 2000 vintage:  Lively cherry and berry fruit, with a hint of cinnamon on the finish. Light and easygoing, but holds your interest.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, September 30, 2001).

Our panel's tasting note: Medium deep ruby colour with aromas of game, smoke, cedar, toast, cassis and graphite. Dry, balanced, medium to full-bodied with a lingering finish. (Oct. 2001)  Food match: lamb medallions in a marsala reduction sauce.

Tasting note: Medium deep ruby colour with aromas of blueberry pie, plum and cedar. Dry, balanced with very good fruit flavours and cedar replays. Medium full-bodied with a long cedar/fruit finish. (David Churchill, Vintages, July 2003).  Food match: barbecued spareribs.  (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).  Speaking of France's Rhone Valley, don't miss two other reds in the release, Mas des Bressades Cuvée Excellence 2001 ($17, No. 708750), full-bodied, concentrated and firm, with flavours of plum and cedar and a luscious texture.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe and Mail, September 6, 2003).
Brillante, Nitido,Fruta Roja, Madera, Seco, Cuerpo medio

Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw colour with aromas of anise, apple, asparagus and apricot. Dry, fresh and lively with a medium body and very good finish. (Source:  Vintages - July 20, 2002 Release)

This is the second label of Château d'Aiguilhe, a winery Robert Parker Jr. calls the "superstar of Côtes de Castillon".  Our panel's tasting note: Deep ruby colour with aromas of cherry, plum and sweet berry. Dry, quite ripe and rich. Medium full-bodied with a solid finish.  Food match: roasted guinea fowl.  (Source:  Vintages, May 2003).
Medium ruby/garnet colour; dry and light- to medium- bodied; blackberry leather and plum aromas and flavours; dry, medium- to full-bodied with moderate tannins and good length

The Château is a beautiful 17th century brick and limestone mansion, called a 'chartreuse' in Bordeaux. It is surrounded by 62 hectares of vineyards and parkland. The legendary 'flying winemaker', Hugh Ryman, is the consulting winemaker. The blend in their red wine is 45% Cabernet Sauvignon, 45% Merlot, 7% Cabernet Franc and 3% of Malbec and Petit Verdot.  (Source:  Vintages, April 5, 2003)  Good colour. Lots of ripe Merlot fruit blended with Cabernet Sauvignon. Score - **** (out of 5). (Steven Spurrier, www.decanter.com, April 2000)  Comments on winery:  Beautiful riverside chateau owned by Gilbeys 1975-2000.  New Owners, so watch this space.  Well-made Crus Bourgeaois and Sauvignon Blanc White from 155 acres.  (Source:  Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book 2003)

Tasting note: Deep ruby/purple colour with aromas of cassis, cherry, mocha and new oak. Dry with a sweet, ripe centre. Full-bodied with a long finish. (VINTAGES panel, March 2004)  Food match: rare roast beef or lamb.

Loupiac sweet wines, made on the right bank of the Garonne River, have always struggled under the giant shadow of the left bank's Sauternes, but in the best hands (and according to the Oxford Companion to Wine, Château Loupiac-Gaudiet is one of the best), it can rival the big brother from across the 'creek'.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw/gold colour with aromas of pineapple, pear and iodine. Medium sweet, supple, very well-balanced, still very young botrytis-affected wine. Medium bodied with an elegant, sweet/crisp finish. Age 4+ years. (Mar. 2002)  Food match: blue-veined cheeses.   (Source:  Vintages, October 5, 2004).

The 2001 Châteauneuf du Pape exhibits classic kirsch liqueur and licorice aromas in a sexy, round, medium to full-bodied style with no hard edges. Plump and plush, it will provide pleasure over the next 8-10 years. Score - 88 (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com, Feb. 2004)  (Vintages, September 17, 2005).

Region: France - Burgundy - Beaujolais Villages - Le Perréon
Notes: Medium ruby/purple colour with aromas of table grape, strawberry and white pepper. Dry, aggressive/lively with good fruit and acid. Medium-bodied with a lingering finish. Will show well with a slight chill. (Vintages panel, May 2003) (Source:  Vintages, February 7, 2004).  Comments on the 1999 vintage:  One of the reasons I like last week's wine, the Cristom Pinot Noir, is that when it's served slightly chilled it's the perfect wine for a hot summer evening. The same advantage applies to this week's offering, the Domaine de la Madone, Le Perreon, Reserve Beaujolais Villages 1999.  I know, I know, but before all you knowledgeable wine lovers turn your noses up at a "mere" Beaujolais Villages and move on to reading about Michael Frank's latest set of sexy wheels, let me assure you that this is very far from your standard-issue Beaujolais. In fact, it's such an exciting and sexy wine that its importer describes it as "so much fun it should be illegal," and he's right.  It actually has more in common with the Cristom Pinot than might at first meet the eye. Gamay, the grape of Beaujolais, is a close relation of pinot noir, and tradition has it that Gamay was developed from its more august cousin in order to yield light, early maturing wine.  These days, though, what a few inventive Beaujolais vignerons (winegrowers) are discovering is that if you modify the traditional Beaujolais methods and treat Gamay like pinot noir, you wind up with a bigger, richer and all together more substantial wine that tastes, well, like a pinot noir.  This is what the Bererd family of Perréon is doing, and very exciting it is too. They are lucky in that they own vineyards with some very old vines--up to 100 years old--that produce small quantities of highly concentrated grapes. Then, by rigorous work in the vineyard, de-stemming the grapes, employing longer fermentation and aging in oak barrels--all of which are a departure from the prevailing Beaujolais custom--they wind up with a Beaujolais of uncommon power and intensity.  During a visit to the Bererds last summer, I sat around the huge oak table in the family dining room and tasted various vintages dating back to 1987. What amazed me was that it was possible to make a "simple" Beaujolais Villages that had this much depth of flavor, or that could last so long. In a blind tasting, I would peg them for Premier Cru Burgundies; that's how good they are.  My favorite was the 1995, because it opened up more than the new vintages and all the elements of flavor were working together in harmony. Unfortunately, it is very hard to find in the U.S., but the later vintages, especially the 1998, make for super current summer drinking when lightly chilled and will age beautifully too.  Bruno Bererd told me, "We prefer bigger wines than the traditional Beaujolais, and I want to prove to many people that we can make more concentrated wines than Beaujolais-Villages is known for." He, along with his father and his brothers, has certainly achieved that.  The 55,000 acres of Beaujolais produce more than 15 million cases of wine every year, much of it, unfortunately, the rather light and unimpressive product that most wine drinkers think of when they hear the name "Beaujolais." Most Beaujolais is made by combining standard burgundy vinification methods with a process called macération carbonique, which lets fermentation take place within the grape. By reducing exposure to the skin, the wines are consistently low in tannin and preponderantly fruity, if not particularly remarkable. Better crus, such as Le Perreon, are made according to traditional methods, which can produce more interesting wines, although not necessarily as long-lived as wines from Burgundy or Bordeaux.  (Source:  Nick Passmore, Forbes Magazine, July 23, 2003).
Purchased in Paris, France
Le Clos des Boucherottes, Monopole

Caractère du vin: Medium - Ample.  Le mariage du vin et des mets: Grillades et barbecues, La viande rouge, Gibier a poils, Fromages forts et mûrs.  A quelle occasion boire le vin?: comme vin de tous les jours, vin de barbecue ou de fete au jardin, vin de repas, pour un lunch ou un diner entre famille ou amis.  Pourquoi acheter ce vin?: Lauréat du vin du Guide d'achat des vins 2002.  Info supplémentaire:  Située face à la petite Camargue, sur le versant sud du Costières de Nîmes, la propriété du Château Saint-Cyrgues réussit le mariage d'exception d'un terroir et un climat. Déjà au 18ème siècle, les moines y cultivaient le vigne. Depuis 1991, Guy de Mercurio oenologue helvétique, y exprime sa passion de la vigne et du vin.  Notes du viticulteur: 'D'un rouge profond aux senteurs agréables d'épices, de cassis et de fruits rouges, typé par des tannins fermes et élégants, il sera en accord parfait avec une viande grillée, un civet de lièvre ou un fromage. Ce vin, élevé naturellement peut présenter un léger dépot.'  Mais d'où sort-on continuellement ces domaines ? Nous découvrons sur notre table ce Costières de Nîmes superensoleillé, qui par son millésime 2000 d'enfer danse le cancan dans notre verre : beaucoup de larmes qui valsent sur le rebord du verre, de couleur bleu-rouge avec des reflets brillants violets. Au nez, on observe un paquet d'arômes mûrs avec surtout les fruits de bois et les prunes bleues qui ressortent. En bouche, on retrouve des arômes de cerises du nord et de cerises-Griotte, ardents et poivrés, mais surtout, en deuxième instance, du cassis mûr et de la pâte de figues vertes.  Un vin avec de beaux muscles bien entrainés, qui démontre l'importance de cette AOC : fruits, fruits, fruits, mais qui possède également la force nécéssaire pour épater tout le monde. Source: Le Guide d'achat des vins 2002

Description:  One of the most dependable domaines in Burgundy, as it has been for 30 years ? They have eliminated one racking during the maturing process. This has led to more sophisticated wines in recent years. (Clive Coates, MW, The Vine, Feb. 2004).  Tasting note: Herbal blackberries can be detected in the aromatics of the 2002 Savigny-Les-Beaune Les Lavieres. Revealing excellent depth of fruit, this light to medium-bodied wine offers loads of red and black berries that lead the taster into a firmly structured back end. Projected maturity: 2006-2010. (Pierre Rovani, www.erobertparker.com, June 2004) (Source:  Vintages, Sep 3, 2005).

Though not officially organic, Château de Combebelle uses biodynamic techniques. That means no chemical sprays and only natural compost is used for fertilizer. The blend here is 70% Syrah and 30% Grenache with a very short time in barrel.  Our panels tasting note: Aromas of black cherry, cassis, oak, hickory smoke and spice. Dry, full-bodied, quite extracted with lots of ripe fruit. The finish lingers. For those diehards, try with a winter barbecued steak. (Source:  Vintages, January 2002 release)

Varietal: merlot pour 70 %, en cabernet franc pour 25 % et en cabernet sauvignon pour le reste

Notes: Crystal clear colour with an elegant nose that evokes the fresh fruits. It contains a good acid structure. Pleasant in the mouth, both elegant and harmonious with an excellent persistence on the finish. What balance it offers! (Revue Bourgogne Aujourd'hui, April/May 2004)
sexy, broad, flesh, low acid wine with an expansive texture, a flamboyant ostentatious bouquet of plums, figs, sweet blackberries, and jammy blackberries, and noticeable, but silky tannins.
currants, blackberries and cherries with hints of vanilla and cedar. Full-bodied, with exuberant fruit. Velvety tannins. Soft and round mouthfeel.

Wine: Domaine Grand Veneur Lirac Clos de Sixte

Notes: The 2009 Alain Jaume Vacqueyras Grande Garrigue is much more backward, displaying a denser blue/purple color, thicker, richer blue and black fruits, and hints of kirsch, lavender, and garrigue. Still grapy and unformed, but loaded with potential given its depth of concentration and richness, it will benefit from another 2-3 months of bottle age, and keep for 5-8 years. Score - 91. (Robert Parker Jr., erobertparker.com, Aug. 2010)

Wine: Clos Saint Jean Chatauneuf-du-Pape Deus-Ex Machina

Notes: Of all the famous white wines of the world, muscadet must be the least fashionable.  The usual explanation is that minerally, muscadet is too neutral in flavour for today's dazzle-me consumers, lacking the crowd-pleasing fruitiness of modern sauvignon blancs and the buttery, mouth-filling character of oak-aged chardonnays. But I'm not so sure. Pinot grigio, Italy's most famous contribution to flavour understatement, is selling like there's no tomorrow. And just look at the startling popularity of vodka, the distilled essence of flavour restraint.  I think muscadet's uncoolness may have more to do with the general trend away from sub-$20 French wines in general, as well as the misleading sound of its name. Muscadet has nothing to do with the musty muscat grape.  Nor is it to be confused with muscatel, the muscat-based dessert wine once associated with hobos.  Muscadet is in fact made from the melon de bourgogne grape in northwest France, where the Loire River empties into the cool Atlantic.  It's the epitome of clean and refreshing, often recommended for shellfish, especially raw oysters.  But it's very suitable as an any-occasion white and, in my book, makes an excellent apéritif. Typically best when young, some muscadets can age beautifully for five to 10 years.  And there may be another reason for muscadet's low profile: the generally unremarkable quality of a few mass-produced brands that tend to dominate North American shelves.  One wine that certainly doesn't fall into that bland category is the excellent, if ostentatiously named, Château du Coing de Saint-Fiacre Muscadet de Sèvre-et-Maine Comte de Saint-Hubert 1999 ($15.95, product No. 799924). It was released last week through Ontario Vintages stores (there was no Vintages column last week because of an unfortunate combination of illness and holidays). This wine is a little more expensive and much more serious than most muscadets, hailing from old vines and kept on its lees, or fermentation sediment, for an extended period.  The nose is lean and classic, with hints of minerals, citrus and salty ocean spray (the real thing, not the cranberry drink). On the palate, it's relatively round and full, with notes of passion fruit, pineapple, pear and mineral and almost spritzy acid.  An excellent match for seafood or soft goat cheese, and a fine candidate for cellaring.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe and Mail, April 12 2003)

A touch of litchi, a hint of peach. Yet, the palate is fully textured with flowers and litchi and peach, all lingering over honeyed lemon drops and gunpowder tea. If you like fish or seafood with forward dried herb flavours or coconut shrimp, drink this with that.  (Source:  www.winereviews.ca, May 2003).  This wine won a Gold Medal at the 2002 Grand Concours des vins d'Alsace. 'Hertz Gewurz' was well received when we previously released the 1996 and 1998 vintages.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium yellow straw colour with aromas of lychee and peach. Medium dry, ripe, fat and very full-bodied. Long, lush finish. Food match: pan-seared sea scallops with lemon, marjoram and butter.  (Source:  Vintages, May 2003).

Wine: Clos Saint Jean Chatauneuf-du-Pape la Combe de Fous
Les Tourelles de Longueville Grand Cru
Notes: great finesse with silky tannins complex black and red fruit

A multi-award winner in 2002, including Golds at Vinalies International and the Concours General Chambre d'Agriculture, both in Paris, a Silver at the International Wine & Spirits Competition and a Bronze at the International Wine Challenge, both in London.  Lezongars is certainly a name to watch. For many years Philip and Sarah Iles ran two very successful dining clubs in London's financial district but Pontac's was bombed out by the IRA in the 1993 Bishopsgate blast and Mr Garraway's [their second restaurant] was encountering problems so they decided to move to Bordeaux to realise a long-held ambition to make rather than sell wine. They bought Château Lezongars (I still don't know what a zongars is) and its 40 hectares of vineyard just in time for the 1998 harvest. Since then the property has been converted to one designed to sell fruity, quite modern wine in bottle rather than in bulk ... L'Enclos du Château Lezongars is a special bottling ... All of [the] wines, described by the Iles family as New Wave Bordeaux, are still quite reasonably priced. (Jancis Robinson MW, www.jancisrobinson.com, Dec. 17, 2002).  Tasting note: Lots of new wood, but also impressive aromas of ripe fruit. Medium-bodied, with silky tannins and a vanilla, berry aftertaste. Best after 2005. Score - 87. (James Suckling, www.winespectator.com, March 31, 2003).  Food match: grilled lamb chops with ratatouille.  (Source:  Vintages, August 2003).  Le fruit y est avec un beau boisé fin. La bouche est assise sur des tanins gras et présents qui assurent une structure fiable. Modérément corsé, déjà mûr et de bonne longueur, il mérite quand même deux ou quatre ans de garde pour gagner en complexité. **(*) Dégusté en juillet 2003.  (Source:  crusetsaveurs.com, September 2003).

If you can bear to give away, these bottles would all make wonderful presents ... the Lezongars would show that you were ahead of the crowd ... Ideal Christmas claret - and for the next six years. Serious but seductive, with ripe mulberry fruit and fine tannins. One of Bordeaux's rising stars, so buy now while you still can.  (Joanna Simon, The Sunday Times, Nov. 21, 2004)
The nose is refined with delicate minerals and oak, followed by apricot and grapefruit. The palate is pleasant green apple with a soft her finish.  (Source:  Mark Handelman web site - September 2001)
Galleries Lafeyette

Tasting note: This is a medium-bodied, richly fruity effort offering plenty of strawberries, black currants, and cherries in an easygoing style meant to be drunk over the next 2-3 years. (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com, April 2003).  Food match: veal medallions in red wine sauce.  (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).

This fresh and stylish wine offers an intense bouquet of black berries, tobacco and spices. A medium body red that possesses smooth, round and well balanced attributes. A consumer friendly and affordable Bordeaux! (Vins et Vignobles, Feb. 2004)

Loire Valley red wines are generally considered drink now' in most years. However, the unusually hot summer of 2003 helped red grapes to fully ripen, resulting in wines of greater depth and firmer tannins  perfect for ageing and futher development. Made from 100% Cabernet Franc, talented 38-year-old François Audebert has crafted a sophisticated wine that sports floral, cherry and blackberry notes, medium body and good grip and length.

Dense, black, opaque colour with garnet rim.  Expressive, intoxicating aromas of black fruits, meat, leather and graphite.  Nose more Grave-like than Margaux.  Full-bodied, concentrated and complex, with rich fruit, generous ripe tannins, a huge mid-palate and a long, spicy, caressing finish.

Apple, pineapple, and mandarins in the nose are tinged with pungency like that of a sea breeze and a whiff of blue cheese. Deep, savory, saline, citric, nutty, and persistently pungent on the palate, this really grips with amazing tenacity and complexity. It should evolve interestingly for 2-3 years.

An alluring nose of Kenya AA coffee and bittersweet cocoa, with polished, racy notes of black currant, fig and loam on the palate. The long, fine-grained finish has a nice minerally spine. Not as dense as the 2003, but with better integration. Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Petit Verdot.  4,000 cases made

Bright purple. Concentrated, powerful scents of cassis and blueberry deepened by vanillin oak and mocha. Sweet dark fruit liqueur flavors are braced by gentle minerality and finish with an exotic note of licorice candy. This really clings to the palate.
60% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Franc, 10% Cabernet Sauvignon
A bright, nicely structured Dolcetto, with ripe plum, berry and clean mineral aromas and flavors. Medium-bodied, with fine tannins and a crisp palate and finish. 905 cases made.

Wine: Barolo Vigna dei Pola Podere di Rivalta di la Morra - Verduno
Notes: A full-on, pedal-to-the-metal adventure down a dusty road, this wine seems to go on forever, flashing past berries and animals toward a smoky, unformed distance. There's a roundness that places it in a modern style, the tannins generous and elegantly handled so they don't stop the flavor from lasting over a minute. This will need six to eight years to reveal itself completely.  (Wine & Spirits Magazine,

Plenty of blackberry and licorice character. Medium- to full-bodied palate, with chewy tannins and a long finish. Mouthpuckering. Big Beaumont. Best after 2007. 35,000 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, March 31, 2003).  Deep ruby/purple, with good sweetness, lushness, and plenty of fruit and glycerin, this medium-bodied, soft Haut-Médoc is ideal for drinking over the next 6-7 years. Score - 87. (Robert Parker Jr., Wine Advocate, April 23, 2003)

Varietal: Merlot (55%), Cabernet Sauvignon (30%), Cabernet Franc (5%) and Malbec (10%)
Notes: Situé sur l'un des plus beaux coteaux de la commune de Bayon, le Château Falfas est chargé dune belle histoire: Aux XIVe et XVe siècles, ce beau domaine appartenait aux Seigneurs de Lansac, vieille noblesse d'épée, fidèles à la couronne d'Angleterre.À cette époque, ses vins étaient exportés avec privilège à la cour des Edouards. Puis le Château fut acquis au XVIIe siècle par les Sires de Riveaux, qui léguèrent au bâtiment actuel son pur style Louis XIII. À la fin du XVIIe siècle, le Château passa dans la maison du Président à mortier du Parlement de Guyenne, Gaillard de Falfas, qui le fit restaurer et lui donna son nom. Aujourd'hui John et Véronique Cohran continuent la tradition pour lui conserver son prestige et sa renommée.  Les 22 hectares du vignoble sont cultivés en biodynamie depuis 1988. Sur un terroir calcaire à astéries, la vigne produit environ 40 hectolitres par hectare. Les vendanges se font à la main pour récolter les meilleurs raisins, et la vinification reste très traditionnelle. Pour conserver toute lauthenticité du vin, la fermentation alcoolique se fait avec les levures indigènes et le vin nest ni collé, ni filtré. Il est élevé au moins un an en barrique. À notre avis, ce Château Falfas fait partie des meilleurs Côtes de Bourg.  (Source:  http://www.7chefs.com, September 2003).  Château Falfas is a member of the ever growing bio-dynamic movement. See sidebar on page 13 for a description of the movement. The wine is a blend of 55% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5% Cabernet Franc and 10% Malbec.  Tasting note: (barrel tasting at the winery) Inky/jet purple colour with intense aromas of ripe black fruits, terroir, minerals plus charred oak notes. Dry, concentrated fruit balanced with oak and mineral complexity. Firm but ripe tannins. Full-bodied with a long lingering finish. Age 5-7 years. (Tami Karakasis, Vintages, Feb 2002).  Food match: confit du canard.  (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).
1996 was excellent year for Vosne Romanee

Dark-colored with intense aromas of spices and blackberries. Full-bodied and chewy, with lots of cool fruit and a long, silky finish. Impressive. Really well-done for the vintage. Best after 2007. Score -- 91. (James Suckling, www.winespectator.com, March 31, 2004)

Varietal: Syrah, Grenache and a touch of Cabernet Sauvignon
Notes: François Pugibet is one of the Languedoc's producers who has helped moved the region towards quality wines.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium ruby colour with aromas of pipe tobacco, raspberry, leather, brambleberry, burnt toffee and smoked meat. Dry, soft, light to medium-bodied red.  Food match: sipping on its own or with barbecued sausage.(Source:  Vintages - August 2002 Release)

Solid, medium-bodied red, with good concentration to its red plum and berry flavors, with spicy and brickish notes on the finish. Drink now. 800 cases imported. (Source: Wine Spectator, June 15, 2002)

Tasting note: A fine expression of Mosel Riesling. Round and succulent, offering peaches and cream accented by lime and slate. Elegant and lively on a light frame, it's perfect for a spring afternoon. Score - 88. (Bruce Sanderson, www.winespectator.com, Marc. 2001).  Food match: wiener schnitzel.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).

Winery: Chateau De La Verdasse Cru Bourgeois

Notes: This estate-bottled Kabinett hails from Schönborn's holdings in the Berg Rottland and Berg Schlossberg vineyards in the village of Ruedesheim in the Rheingau. This wine was harvested on a very significant day - October 3rd, 1990 - the day of the reunification of East and West Germany.  (Source:  Vintages, August 2003).  Un super achat que ce vin qui aura treize ans dans quelques semaines. Vinifié en sec, il embaume le caractère minéral du riesling de plus de dix ans ainsi que la cire. Très vif et droit, à pleine maturité et aérien par la qualité de ses arômes persistants desquels une touche de caramel ajoute à la complexité. À ne pas manquer. *** Dégusté en juillet 2003.  (Source:  crusetsaveurs.com, September 2003).

Vintages tasting note: Medium yellow gold colour with aromas of green plum, pears, peaches, mineral and a hint of olive oil and nutmeg. Medium in sweetness with excellent fruit and nutmeg replays. Good acids still for balance, but very drinkable now. Medium-bodied with a long finish.  Food match: pan-seared scallops with Chinese greens.  (Vintages - February 8, 2003 release, tasted in June 2002)

Wine: Bernkasteler alte Badstube am Doctorberg Riesling Kabinett
Notes: Dense and crammed with apricot, nectarine and orange flavors, this tastes like a little botrytis is present. Impressive, with spätlese ripeness and a long, long finish, but it loses some clarity with the concentration. Drink now through 2010. 300 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, February 28, 2003)

This house keeps shipping fully mature rieslings to Ontario. A great opportunity to explore the genre. This shows classic, lifted, spicy peach, canned mandarin fruit on the nose with fragrant spruce needle, mossy spiciness and lots of mature petrol ... Very good to excellent length. Don't overchill, try it with rich pork dishes, white cheeses and dried fruit snacks. (David Lawrason, Wine Access First In Line E-Report, Apr. 2002)

Tasting Notes:  Pale yellow colour; floral/spicy aromas; soft semi-sweet fruit flavour; persistent finish.  Serving Suggestion:  Oriental buffet; smoked salmon; mildly spiced foods (Vintages web site, April 24, 2005).

Medium straw colour with aromas of clover blossom, apricot, mineral, green apple and melon. Medium dry with a lively crispness and excellent structure. Medium full-bodied with a lingering crisp/fruit finish. Food match: sweet and sour dishes.Tasted in Sept. 2002.  (Source:  Vintages, May 10, 2003).  Another terrific, slightly sweet white in the release is Dr. H. Thanisch Riesling Kabinett 1998 ($19.95, No. 730838). Made in Germany's Mosel region, it's medium full-bodied with notes of green apple, peach, petrol and mineral, with firm, cleansing acidity.  (Source:  Globe and Mail, Beppi Crosariol, May 10, 2003).
Purchased in Hockenheim, Germany
Purchased in Berlin, Germany

This handsome Pinot features pungent cherry and floral aromas, and flavours of cherry, floral, and woodspice with beguiling earth notes. It's light- to medium-bodied and sports an attractive, medium-plus finish. (VINTAGES panel, Feb. 2009)

The news out of Germany is great once again. After a lacklustre harvest in 2000, which broke a string of consecutive great years dating back to the fall of the Berlin Wall, German riesling is again riding high. Wines from the superb 2001 harvest are reaching Canadian shelves and represent some of the freshest, fruitiest, most interesting whites around. They're also arriving just in time for light and lively spring and summer menus, with which they pair so well.  And the nice thing about German riesling, as connoisseurs know, is that many can be laid down for years. Some German rieslings have the concentration and acidity, the perfect balance, to age beautifully for a decade or more.  Sommeliers at fine restaurants are scooping up 2001s from such top producers as St.-Urbans-Hof and Schloss Schonborn, proclaiming the vintage the finest since 1975 or even perhaps the legendary 1971.  A dry October in much of the country in 2001 yielded concentrated grapes with intense, complex flavours. Paradoxically, it's that intensity, coupled with varying degrees of sweetness, that turn off many wine newcomers who prefer the lean, zippy crowd-pleasing quaffability of such popular whites as pinot grigio and sauvignon blanc. But if there's a time to explore the rewarding, food-friendly flavours of riesling, it's now.  A good place to start is with Reichsrat von Buhl Forster Bischofsgarten Riesling Kabinett 2001 from the Pfalz region ($19.95, product No. 988527), which goes on sale today in Ontario as part of Vintages' first June release. It's medium-dry and almost medium-bodied, with rich flavours of canned-peach and honey. The balancing acidity gives it a delicious lift and would make it a lovely apéritif to kick off a summer dinner party.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 7, 2003).  Our panel's tasting note: Classic Pfalz Riesling. Pale straw colour with aromas of peach, apricot and floral tones. Medium-dry with a persistent balance between fruit and acid. Light to medium-bodied with a good finish. (Sept. 2002)  Food match: aperitif.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Packed with white pepper and peach, this Riesling reveals its bracing structure on the finish. Drink now through 2007. 2,830 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, March 31, 2003).  On the drier side, don't miss Dr. Burklin-Wolf Riesling 2001 ($21.95, No. 991315). This wine, also from the Pfalz region, has an uncanny but appealing aroma of wine gums, those chewy candies from the variety store. On the palate, it's light-bodied with just a hint of residual sugar, exhibiting flavours of pear, citrus and tropical fruit. Try it with lightly prepared, flaky fish.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 7, 2003).  Our panel's tasting note: Pale to medium straw colour with aromas of pear, tangerine, guava, grapefruit and lime. Off-dry with a tangy refreshing mid-palate. Medium-bodied with a crisp, enlivening finish. (Sept. 2002)  Food match: grilled salmon with a lemon sauce.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Tasting note: An excellent value, the 2001 Scheurebe Kabinett Halbtrocken Grosskarlbacher Burgweg offers a sappy nose of spicy yellow fruits. Sea salt, olive oil, loads of red currants, and cherries can be discerned in its extroverted personality. Medium-bodied and silky-textured, this is an elegant Scheurebe with admirable depth of fruit and outstanding length. Drink it over the next 5-7 years. Score - 90. (Pierre-Antoine Rovani, www.erobertparker.com, Dec. 2002).  (Source:  Vintages, August 2003).

Brilliance and clarity highlight this Riesling, whose peach, grapefruit and spice notes are brought into focus against the vivid structure. Subtle, lingering finish. Drink now through 2006. 5,000 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, March 31, 2003)

Peach, apple and mineral flavors mingle in this bright, moderately firm kabinett. Open and accessible, with a juicy finish. Drink now through 2006. 4,000 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, March 31, 2003)

Minéral et fleurs blanches avec des nuances de lime.  Un vin demi-sec équilibré par une acidité nerveuse.  Lége, racé et long.  Garde possible de 10 ans.  Très fin.  Quote:  2-3 sourires.   (Source:  www.crusetsaveurs.com, lettre de Alain Laliberté, 19 février 2003).

Wine: J. & H. A. Strub Niersteiner Paterberg Riesling Spatlese

Notes: ripe red fruit aromas and flavours, notes of cedar and spice
intense dark fruit spice and vanilla polished tannins
full body red but soft great buy eric soloman euopean cellars
Canary Islands holiday wine

Round, ripe and packed with complex aromas and flavors of peach, orange, lime and slate, this is a serious kabinett. Its richness is offset by a vivid structure, keeping it all focused through the long finish. Drink now through 2010. 225 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, March 31, 2003).

Notes: outstanding by WE, IWC, WS
lively red soft red berries and plum

Wine: Warre's Otima 10 Year Old Tawny Port

Notes: Tasting note: Appearance: dense purple. Nose: blackberry with evident alcohol. Taste: sweet, intense, lots of flavour, blackberry, black cherry with a hot alcoholic finish. Score  **** (out of 5). (Tony Aspler, www.tonyaspler.com, Aug. 22, 2003).  Food match:  fruit flans, aged cheeses.  (Source:  July 24, 2004).  Six Grapes is one of Graham's original Port blends and is thus one of the Company's oldest marks.  It is a very full-bodied, luscious wine drawn from the same vineyards as Graham's Vintage Ports. Blended from two or three years' harvests, the wine is an average of five to six years old when bottled. It follows the Graham's Vintage style very closely, although it has softened more quickly by being matured in oak casks rather than in bottle. Its extremely rich fruity style makes it a truly superb, rare and appealing Port.  (Source:  Graham's web site, August 16, 2004).
subtle red wine with warm fruity flavours
hints of nectarine and grassy, gooseberry aromas and flavours
nectarine, freshly cut grass aromas and gooseberry flavours
Rich luscious white wine baked fruit flavours with touch of honey

Winery: Baron de Ley S A Mendavia SPAIN
Baron de Ley S A Mendavia SPAIN

Notes: Honeymoon purchase

Nez de marmelade d'orange et de zeste de citron avec des arômes de miel, de thé et d'abricot frais. En bouche, ce vin corsé rappelle les notes de thé, de marmelade d'oranges et de miel.  Savourez-le à lheure du dessert avec une crème caramel à lorange ou des baklavas.   (Source:  SAQ.com, February 22, 2004).  Un vin doux naturel délicieux, fait avec du raisin muscat. À prendre à l'apéritif, avec le dessert ou en soirée. Bien à la température de la pièce, mais sera encore mieux légèrement rafraîchi. Un bon vin fruité, légèrement sucré et un bouquet de prune. Bien moins cher que les autres vins de muscat produit en France.  (Source:  Vin Quebec, October 2000).
Deep red colour, aromas of red fruits with hints of chocolate, coffee and cinamon in harmony with the vanilla of the oak. Medium structured body with fine tannins.
abby greece trip
No date on label, 13.5%

Comments on 1997 vintage:  Powerful, muscular red, with loads of ripe plum, berry and dark cherry flavors. Notes of tobacco box and bittersweet chocolate on the finish. Needs at bit more time to smooth out the edges. Best from 2003 through 2006. 500 cases imported.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, May 15, 2002).  'Vinha Grande' is made from grapes one normally associates with Port: Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional, Touriga Francesa and Tinto Barroca. The resulting dry wines tend to be deeply coloured and very robust. This is a wine that is made only in the best years. For example, the winery did not make this wine in 1998.   Our panel's tasting note: Deep ruby colour with aromas of berry, plum leather, cedar/new oak and fresh sage. Dry, balanced, fairly big wine. Medium-bodied with a lingering finish. Food match: pork roast.  (Source:  Vintages, May 2003).

Made with 100% Alvarinho, the grape considered the best in the Vinho Verde. Wines made exclusively with this grape are fuller and more complex than most others from this region.  Vintages tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of peach and apricot. Very dry, crisp with a nice refreshing spritz. Zippy palate refresher before a meal or after a long day. Medium-bodied with a medium-long finish. (David Churchill, March 2003)  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Comments on 2000 vintage:  Nice peachy notes mark this light white, which finishes on a slightly sweet note. 4,250 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, August 31, 2001).  Sogrape Morgadio da Torre 2001 from Portugal ($16.95, No. 960955) is light and slightly spritzy and perfect for summer sipping.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 21, 2003).

Varietal: Touriga Franca, Tinta Roriz, Tinta Barroca

This blend of indigenous Arinto and international Chardonnay is Portugal's very intelligent reaction to the pressure to plant more international grapes. This blend creates a taste unique to Portugal.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw colour with aromas of lemon, mineral and a hint of smoke. Dry, round and quite full-bodied with a lingering, balanced finish. (Oct. 2002)  Food match: grilled chicken breasts.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).

Another ageable winner from one of the leading estates in the lower Douro. Deep ruby/violet colour leads to aromas that suggest cherry, blackcurrant, spice, tobacco, coffee and smoked meat. Dry with good fruit beneath the firm tannins. Give this 4-5 years to really strut its stuff.  (VINTAGES panel, April 2005)

Amazing aromas of orange and lemon peel, with hints of toffee, caramel and honey. Full-bodied and luscious, with lots of sweet fruit and a long, subtle finish that goes on and on. A benchmark for 10-year-old tawnies. Drink now. 1,500 cases made. (JS)

With approximately 40% of the blend derived from the legendary Port grape Touriga Nacional, Quinta dos Roques' dry red 2002 is a full-flavoured fruity blockbuster with a good core of acid and tannin for balance. Enjoyable now with rare cuts of beef, lamb or venison, it should also improve with some time in bottle.

Quinta do Crasto is still one of the traditionalists in the Douro. They handpick their grapes (mind you, the vineyards are on a such steep angle that mechanical picking would be impossible) and foot trod the grapes in the low-sided wooden troughs called lagares. As this LBV is unfiltered, it is advisable to decant before serving as it will throw a sediment.  (Source:  LCBO web site, May 2003).
Vinho do casamento da Juliana
Cliff Richard wine

An integrated blend of 60% cabaret sauvignon and pinot noir. Balanced and harmonious, this cuvee is supple on the palate but with enough tannin for a grip. Well blended flavors of cherry and plum with a hint of spice. Enjoyable now but will be even better in a few years.

Lovely complexity, showing orange, smoke and black tea notes matched to a light, lively structure. Well-balanced, with lingering accents of caramel and marmalade. Drink now through 2006. 3,000 cases made. (Wine Spectator, October 31, 2003).

Tasting note: Medium yellow gold colour with aromas of dried pear, camomille, linden leaf, nuts and a pleasing oxidative note. Medium sweet, intense, round and smooth. Rich, full-bodied, long finish. (Vintages panel, March 2003).  Food match: pecan pie, crème brûlée.   (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).

Our panel's tasting note: Very aromatic medium straw gold colour with aromas of smoke, dried apricot, dried marjoram, autumn asters and golden rod. Gently dry with a crisp mid-palate. Quite full-bodied with a long finish. Enjoy with crown roast of pork. (Sept. 2001).  (Source:  Vintages, May 2002).

This characteristically spicy, deep ruby coloured wine offers an enormously beautiful aroma, with paprika, plum and blackberry. Ideal for dinner parties. Recommended with game dishes and roasts. Best enjoyed cooled at a temperature of 16-18°C .
given as a wedding gift from laura birek
Medium-bodied, rich fragrant red wine. Lightly wooded, fermented dry on the skins for a few days for a fruitier style. Best with pates, cheese, goulash and red meats.

Wine: Fleur du Cap Unfiltered Sauvignon Blanc

Notes: got 15% off and then another 10%, so real cost about 13.00

The grapes came from vineyard blocks which face both north-south and east-west, and which are situated at 220 to 350 metres above sea level. The vines are ... grown in decomposed granite and lime soils with clay subsoils ... Two of the sauvignon vineyard blocks are older vines planted in 1977, while the third dates back to 1996 and has now settled in well. (www.wine.co.za).  Food match: grilled prawns.  (Source:  Vintages, November 15, 2003).

Tasting Note:  Medium ruby colour; dry and medium-bodied with ripe plum and cherry fruit; hints of smoke and spice with soft tannins and good length.  Serving Suggestion: Grilled or roasted red meats; medium cheeses.  (Source:  Vintages web site, August 16, 2004).

Though the 2000 vintage had not been reviewed at press time (very early reports indicate it is a wine that needs some mid to long-term ageing), John Platter South African Wines 2003 generally rates the wine **** 1/2 (out of five). Only made with the best estate lots of fruit, the wine's name is a tribute to Cyril Back, father (and South African Shiraz pioneer) of current owner, Charles Back. Fairview Wines is one of the best producers, not only in Paarl, but in all of South Africa. It is their attention to detail that allows this phenomenal producer to continue to go from strength to strength.  (Source:  Vintages, April 2003).  Comments on 1999 vintage:  Smells like raspberry compote, with succulent raspberry and blackberry fruit, plus a healthy dollop of sweet, creamy toast on the mouthfilling finish. Very hard not to like this. Drink now through 2003. 1,000 cases made.  (Source: Wine Spectator, October 31, 2001).

Winery: Fairview The Wines of Charles Back
Wine: Goats do Roam in Villages Red

Notes: Cathedral Cellars is the premium brand of KWV, still the Cape's leading wine producer. '[The] 1997 came in two versions (part of a terroir experiment): Paarl, more open, approachable, balanced with generous choc/mulberry tastes. Stellenbosch, demonstratably tighter, more 'serious' with firmer tannins for long-term cellaring.' (Colin Frith, John Platter South African Wines 2002).  (Source:  Vintages, December 2002).
Comments on the 2000 vintage:  Ripe and straightforward, with fresh pear and apple flavors and a toasty finish. 4,000 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, April 30, 2001).

Nez intense et lourd qui respire lasperge et la groseille blanche. Très belle acidité en attaque, du corps avec cette acidité qui sintensifie en évolution, bonne générosité de lalcool et fraîcheur finale. ** Dégusté en juillet 2003.  (Source:  crusetsaveurs.com, September 2003).  Tasting note: Good value. Immediately expressive, unadorned sauvignon with reserves to develop. 02 with scintillating, med-bodied elegance; tangy gooseberry, asparagus intensity, depth; grows with polished urgency to fresh finish. 12.5% alc. Score - **** (out of 5). (Angela Lloyd, John Platter South African Wines 2003).

Well-structured, medium-bodied red, with pretty flavors of raspberry, cassis and spice, with some nice mineral notes mixed in. Firm finish of mocha and vanilla.  Score - 88.  ( Kim Marcus, www.winespectator.com, May 31, 2003)

Region: South Africa - Breede River Valley - Robertson
Notes: Muscadel is the South African name of the noblest for the Muscat grapes, Muscat Blanc à Petits Grains.  Tasting note: [Robert Frost's quote] "We love the things we love for what they are" adorns the back label, [perhaps] hints a cellar philosophy: good ol' (white) muscadel made (seriously) better. Latest 1998 [has] honeycomb richness; sprig spearmint a cloy-buster spirit rush reminds this is 'sweet dessert liqueur wine'. Aperitif, restorative over crushed ice, chilled with biscotti, sabayon-napped summer fruits, delicious any way. (Dave Swingler, John Platter South African Wines 2003)  (Source:  Vintages, October 4, 2003).  Comments on 1996 vintage:  This sweet wine has a lot of white peach and kumquat flavors, with a soft texture and an easygoing finish. 465 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, April 30, 2001).

Region: South Africa - Breede River Valley - Robertson
Notes: Tasting note: Already jam-packed with 'drink me!' individuality, cellar's single vineyard flagship gets ripe boost from fulsome 2000 vintage. Warm cinnamon, white pepper, roasted nuts abound in hugely concentrated mouthful, sensational length to the finish. Riveting, and so much better in 4-6 years. Part barrel-fermented. 14 months mix American/French casks. (Dave Swingler, John Platter South African Wines 2003)

Tasting note: Dryland, mature-vine (60% beyond their teens) fruit gets Am oak (30% new) grooming, emerges svelte and seductive. 01 dense colour, spiced relish, firm tannin cradles delicious fruit. Score - ***** (out of 5). (Dave Swingler, John Platter South African Wines 2003)

Cabernet Franc is used frequently in South Africa's Bordeaux-blends, but it is still quite rare as a single varietal wine. Currently, only .5% of total vines planted in South Africa are Cabernet Franc.  Tasting note: (barrel sample) Well balanced with potential for 3-4 years [ageing]. (John Platter South African Wines 2003)  Food match: spaghetti and meat balls.

Lots of aromas of grapefruit, citrus, quince, melon, and perfume. Could be oaked. Smooth and easy, quite full bodied, with a long, agreeably tart finish. Nice work.  (Source:  The Frugal Oenophile web site - March 2002)

Shows more nut and straw notes, and a round, touch earthy finish. Good, but lacks zip. Not imported into the U.S. Drink now. (Source:  Wine Spectator web site, 2002).  Note de dégustation : Les amateurs de sauvignon blanc qui n'aiment pas particulièrement les versions extrêmes du cépage seront charmés par ce 2001 soigneusement façonné. La maison Forrester en a fait spécifiquement un vin de table aux saveurs souples et minérales d'o÷ émergent la figue verte et un caractère sec ½ souhait. La vive acidité juteuse égaie merveilleusement l'ensemble[...]Bon rapport qualité-prix. (Angela Lloyd, John Platter South African Wines 2002)

Tasting note: 2000 riper, altogether bigger ... than previous, more robust tannin. [In] mid-2002 showing ripe plum/cassis fruit and still firmish tannins, which should smooth in another year or two. Score - **** (out of 5). (Dave Hughes, John Platter South African Wines 2003)

Also a good buy from South Africa is Kanu Chenin Blanc 2003 ($11.50, No. 907089), zesty and rather full, with citrus and melon flavours and a hint of spice.  (Beppi Crosariol, Globe and Mail, November 15, 2003).  Comments on 2002 vintage:  Lovely orange blossom and white peach flavors that are offset by a bracing mineral streak. Finishes with a hint of honeycomb. A textbook Chenin that's hard to resist. Drink now through 2003. 6,585 cases made.  (Wine Spectator, October 31, 2002).

Yes, the winery is owned by legendary race car driver Mario Andretti. As the winery says, it is ironic that a man who made his living driving 200 mph would be devoted to something that cannot be rushed: winemaking.  Our panel's tasting note: Deep ruby colour with aromas of cassis and black cherry. Dry, good aroma replays, some nice dusty tannins, medium full-bodied with a good 'grippy' finish. Food match: pheasant with a wine reduction sauce.  (Source:  Vintages, January 11, 2003 release)  Wine Spectator comments on the 1997 vintage:  A bit austere, but the flavors of black currants, herbs and toasty oak stand up to the dry tannins. Drink now through 2004. 2,600 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, October 31, 2000).
Zesty, with lemon-lime, spice and peppery notes. Drink now. 1,579 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator - 2002)

A wine of great depth. The color is an intense, opaque purple. It exhibits an extremely fragrant bouquet beginning with dark fruit, blackberry, blueberry, and rich dark chocolate, finishing with the sweet scent of soft leather. Layers of flavor fill the mouth and explode on the back of the palate. The wines focus is a core of powerful yet elegant tannins, boasting a finish that lasts over 45 seconds. This is a wine that will drink well for 10-15 years.

Notes: A quite attractive off-dry Riesling with good acidity and pleasant flavours of peach and tropical fruit. Suitably chilled, it's a great match for spicy Thai food. (RP)

Old gold colour with aromas of apricot jam, guava, mineral, peach and roasted hazelnut. Sweet with good citrus tone to refresh. Nutty mid-palate with layers of honey and fruit. Medium full-bodied with a fairly long finish.  (Source:  Vintages, December 2002).

Harvested over 23 brix. Aged 12 months in a combination of French and American oak barrels. 2900 cases bottled March 2002. Dark color, concentrated flavors with hints of black tea, blueberry, and mint. Soft, approachable finish.

An incredibly complex bouquet features black cherry fruit complemented by hints of mahogany, chocolate, mint, honey, leather and tobacco. Big and smooth bodied with full blackberry fruit flavours ornamented by many of the same nuances as the bouquet together with cola and licorice. A truly beautiful, complex, mouthfilling Cabernet Franc.

website: This big, full flavoured wine displays the best of Pinot Noir characteristics - full body and rich flavours combined with smoothness and elegance. A deep, complex bouquet marries ripe berry aromas with toasty oak to produce nuances of cherry, raspberry, cola, mahogany, leather and chocolate which are echoed on the palate ornamenting the deep chocolate cherry flavours. Its rich intensity is made elegant by velvety tannins and smooth mouthfeel. An outstanding Pinot Noir.

47 Cab /37 Merlot/16 Cab Franc/14.7% - Appealing for its' layers of dark fruit with a hint of spice, olives, and cedar on the nose. Full bodied and balanced with silky velvety tannins and a great lengthy rich finish.

Growing organic grapes isn't easy. Wine vines can be vulnerable to all sorts of disease and pestilence, and producing a crop without at least some help from synthetic chemicals demands meticulous care and tending in the field. That's why organic wines tend to carry a price premium.  But it's hard to see where they hid the premium in Perrin Nature Côtes-du-Rhône 2000 ($14, No. 948059), one of the best-value reds of today's Ontario Vintages release. A blend of syrah and grenache, it's medium full-bodied and deliciously savoury, with hints of dried herbs, licorice and black pepper -- a terrific Côtes-du-Rhône even for those who aren't looking for things organic. It would make a good match for grilled or roasted chicken and hearty red-meat dishes.  Domaines Perrin, incidentally, is the all-organic winery behind Château de Beaucastel -- one of the best Châteauneuf-du-Pape estates -- as well as the popular La Vieille Ferme line of budget-priced wines from southern France.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 21, 2003).

Purchasing a wine from this family is about as close to a guarantee of authenticity and high quality as one can expect ... One of the top Gigondas of the vintage, it is a cooler climate wine than the Vacqueyras (as one might expect from these higher elevation vineyards) exhibiting a deep ruby/purple color along with notes of crushed rocks, spring flowers, raspberries, black cherries and hints of lavender as well as graphite. Beautifully rich, elegant and powerful, it should drink well for a decade or more. Score - 91-93. (Robert Parker Jr., erobertparker.com, Oct. 2010)

This 100% Tempranillo (locally called Tinta de Toro) is aged in French and American oak for one year. Mid-term cellar candidate (5-7 years).  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).  Comments on 1999 vintage:  A smooth, dense texture carries rich yet somewhat reticent flavors of plums, prunes, chocolate and toast in this powerful red. It has lovely balance, and strength without flashiness. Drink now through 2010. 300 cases imported.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, September 15, 2002).

Vino Nobile di Montepulciano has been lauded as a majestic growing region as far back as the 16th century when, in 1549, Pope Paul III's cellar master praised them as 'perfect wines'. Praise continued until the 1960s when, like much of the red wines of Tuscany, the reputation suffered. However, in the 1980s, when the rules were slackened to allow the elimination of the white grape Malvasia from the blend, Vino Nobile's place in the wine world soared once again. Under the current DOCG rules, producers are only allowed to use 80% of the superior Prugnolo Gentile Sangiovese clone in their wines. Many of the better producers openly flout this and use only this clone in their wines. Today, innovative producers also continue to push the quality of the wines, experimenting with small barrels, careful pruning and rigorous winery work.  Tasting note: Tuscany enjoyed fine harvests after the blockbuster '97, so don't overlook buys such as this...Very pretty aromas of spices, berries and minerals herald this medium-to full-bodied Tuscan red, with firm, polished tannins and medium finish. Best from 2003 through 2008. Smart Buy. Score - 89. (James Suckling, Wine Spectator, Sept. 19, 2002)  Food match: rare beef dishes with a side order of wild mushroom risotto.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, September 6, 2003).

Deep ruby colour with aromas of blackberry, plum, spice, cassis and a hint of earth. Dry, firm and closed. This full-bodied wine will definitely reward mid-term cellaring (6+ years). (Vintages panel, Nov. 2003)  Château Peyre-Lebade veils a rich historical heritage, marked by several famous individuals. The limestone-rich geology of the site certainly influenced the name of the property, since Peyre-Lebade means Raised-Rock (pierre levée). Indeed, the site features a former limestone quarry, which was probably used in building the neighboring villages.  The first traces of viticulture on the site date back to the Cistercien monks of the Vertheuil Abbey in the 12th century.  Several centuries later, in 1835, Bertrand Redon, who was Odilon Redons father, purchased the Peyre-Lebade estate. The great painter Odilon Redon lived and painted most of his most famous paintings at this estate. His work reflects the sites charm, as well as his attachment to the family property. By 1979, the property had fallen into neglect, and was acquired by Baron Edmond de Rothschild, who was already the owner of the neighboring vineyards of Château Clarke in Listrac and Château Malmaison at Moulis. As of that date, Château Peyre-Lebade would undergo great changes in cultivation and quality under the direction of Baron Edmond. The vineyards were also drained and then replanted, and the buildings were renovated and completed by new constructions. Château Peyre-Lebade is now an integral part of Baron Benjamin (son of Edmond) de Rothschilds properties. Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) handles the marketing of its wines.  (Source:  http://www.lafite.com)

This rare grape is a mutation of Sauvignon Blanc. On the nose, it tends to be much more aromatic than Sauvignon Blanc, and on the palate it exhibits a charming spiciness. Chilean Sommelier Héctor Vergara suggests matching this Sauvignon Gris with delicately flavoured fish, lobster or a seafood risotto.  Vintages tasting note: Pale straw/platinum colour with aromas of pear, fennel, citrus and straw. Dry, excellent pear/fennel replays. Gentle crispness keeps the wine balanced. Medium body and finish. (Source:  Vintages, March 2002).  Comments on 2001 vintage:  Distinctive sweet pea, chive and white peach flavors are bright and tangy, with a chalky finish. Has character. Drink now. 3,000 cases made.   (Source:  Wine Spectator, October 15, 2002).

is massive wine has flavors of cherry, cassis and black currant that seem to fight for the palates attention. Scents of dill, sage and sweet tobacco excite the senses, while exhibiting a bold mouth feel backed by firm, yet refined tannins and perfectly balanced acidity. Ending with flavors of oak and vanilla, this wine has it all.

Not every vintage is ideal to make a late harvest style wine because you really need the perfect ripening conditions to remain at length until the fruit is at its optimum sugar level, about 36 brix. Fortunately, 2004 was such a year. This special wine is made entirely from Zinfandel grapes left to hang until just before the first rains begin to fall. It is a uniquely viscous monster with ultra-ripe dusty blackberry and peppery aromas that emanate from the glass. Mouth coating flavors of blueberry, rich white chocolate and gooseberry are framed by a silky, velvety backbone. Ending with lingering spice and vanilla-berry. This handcrafted Late Harvest Zinfandel will surely have people praying to Mother Nature for the next perfect vintage!

This wine is made by the brilliant Libourne/St.-Emilion doctor and château owner, Dr. Alain Raynaud. This is his first venture in southern France, and the results are very impressive. This offering is personally made by Dr. Raynaud from vineyards owned by Cave de l'Abbé Rous. As of May, 2004, there is no American importer, probably because Banyuls is not a household name for most American wine consumers, which is a shame.
