The Barbera variety's origins are extremely ancient but the first documents in which it is cited date to only several centuries ago. In fact, the first formal citation of Barbera appears in a document of the 17th century that is nowpreserved in the city hall of Nizza Monferrato. And it was first officially mentioned in 1798 when Count Nuvolone, deputy director of the agrarian society of Turin, drew up the first ampelography of the varieties cultivated in the vineyards of Piedmont. "Il" or "la" Barbera, as it was traditionally called by Piedmontese farmers, whose brusk and unassuming character is precisely the same as that of this frank and robust red, is one of the wines best known and appreciated throughout Italy for its generosity and strength. A. Strucchi, a noted Italian enologist, observed at the end of the last century, that "when Barbera wine has attained five or six years of age, it is as suitable for consumption with roasted meats as Barolo and is often preferred by many to the more famous wine.''
Wine Club

Brunello di Montalcino was the first Italian wine to be granted Denominazione di Origine Controlata e Garantita (D O C G) status by the Ministry of Agriculture. There are only 19 DOCG wines, a coveted status which limits fruit per hectare (eight tonnes), and at least 36 months of barrel aging and one year in the bottle.

This wine is a superior quality Asti Barbera, aged 12 months in small French oak barrels and refined 12 months in bottle. Wine obtained from Barbera grapes growing in Villa Fiorita estate on southwest exposed areas where the soil is rich in limestone and clay. The harmony, class and structure of this wine are the outcome of hard and patient work in the vineyards, careful grape selection, and controlled temperature fermentation. The result of a generous harvest, this wine has been refined in new Troncais and Nevers French oak barrels. This elegant wine can be served now or stored for 10+ years.

One of the better values I've tasted in some time was released into the Ontario market earlier this year. Les Fumées Blanches 2001 ($8.95, product No. 472555) is a deliciously crisp white from southern France made from 100 per cent sauvignon blanc. A blend of grapes from warm and cool microclimates for a ripe yet zesty style, it's lean and clean, offering pronounced fruit flavours of pineapple, peach and grapefruit, accented by hints of minerals and honey. This would be a terrific choice for summer patio sipping and a fine partner for salads and grilled seafood.  The name comes from the term given to the white "smoke," or mist, that blankets the hills of southern France's Languedoc region, where the wine is produced. It's also a play on the American term fumé blanc, which typically denotes a barrel-aged sauvignon blanc, although this delicate beauty sees no oak and is the essence of freshness.  Already the top-selling French vin-de-pays white in Quebec, Les Fumées Blanches sells more than 100,000 cases worldwide. It's made by famous "flying winemakers" Jacques and Francois Lurton, who also own properties in Spain, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay. Sons of famous Bordeaux producer André Lurton of Château Bonnet fame, the Lurton brothers, both in their mid-40s, started their first winery in 1988 after a thriving early career as consultants to such major producers as France's Remy Panier and Australia's Hardy and the distribution companies Sainsbury and Tesco. They've been tremendously successful, too, garnering a wealth of medals for their smartly balanced wines.  (Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, July 5, 2003).

In 1976, Neil and Maria Empson were the first international wine experts to export Chardonnay from Italy. They created the 'Bollini' Chardonnay in 1982 to market the wines under their own imprimatur. The wine met with such success, they introduced a full 'Bollini' line of wines shortly thereafter. The Chardonnay 'Barricato 40' is 40% fermented in new French barriques.   Food match: smoked turkey breast.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Among the whites, I was impressed with Bollini Chardonnay Barricato 40 2001 ($12.95, product No. 987503), made by Empson & Co., a consistently good producer of value-priced wines in northern Italy's Trentino region. It's medium-bodied, with flavours of pear and pineapple, deliciously balanced with crisp acidity. The "40" in its name refers to the fact that 40 per cent of the juice was fermented in French oak barrels, imparting a nicely understated flavour of vanilla and a silky texture. A terrific, balanced chardonnay for everyday.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 21, 2003).

The 2001 Merlot 25th Anniversary is a deep ruby/purple-colored effort with a big, sweet, chocolatey nose intermixed with black cherry, curranty fruits, a succulent mouthfeel, and admirable fruit purity in the finish. It is a wine meant to be drunk during its first 7-8 years of life. This beautiful winery, located in Spring Mountain in the Mayacamas Range, seems to be making the best wine of its 25-year history, and much of the credit must go to the tireless efforts of Michael Keenan who has done so much to resurrect the fortunes of this winery. Wine Spectator April 1997 - Delicious already, this is bursting with berry, black cherry, spice and vanilla flavors that remain juicy through the racy finish. With a bit more grip it would be a real ager, too. A blend of Zinfandel and Petite Sirah. 300 cases made.  This wine is a blend of 50% Zinfandel from Cucamonga and 50% Petite Sirah from Pope Valley. The grapes were fermented in small, open top vats. The must was fortified at 12 brix and left on the skins for an additional 2 weeks before pressing. The wine was aged for 2 years in both French and American oak before bottling in October 1996. The resulting wine contains 16.2% alcohol and 9.35% residual sugar. It is well suited as an after dinner and dessert wine.

91 points Robert Parker: "Exhibiting sensational richness and purity, the full-bodied 2004 Shiraz Hyland possesses toasty new oak, blackberry, black currant, raspberry, and cherry characteristics. Layered, deep, medium to full-bodied, and elegant, this 2004 should drink beautifully for a decade or more." (12/06) 90 points Stephen Tanzer's International Wine Cellar: "Dark red. Suave, sexy aromas of blackcurrant, cherry, roasted coffee, vanilla and baking spices. Fat, velvety and sweet, with lush red and dark berry flavors that expand and deepen with air. Finishes with an impressively concentrated cherry preserve flavor and soft tannins." (Jul/Aug 06) Wine Advocate # 168

The non-vintage Victoria Tawny exhibits a medium ruby/amber color as well as plenty of strawberry and cherry fruit. Although the least distinguished of this group, it is a very good Tawny Port imitation. These Australian treasures are fabulous to drink at the end of a meal. Moreover, once opened, they will hold for several weeks, sometimes longer.
2000 cases made

Supple, subtle and distinctive for the way it balances its ripe blackberry and plum fruit against peppery spice and lively but not overwhelming acidity. This has presence. Best from 2008 through 2014. 16,000 cases imported. HS

Grape Tray; Deep, dense and dramatic, with tiers of black cherry, raspberry, and dark chocolate flavors, finishing with wisps of dried cherry and mineral notes, reminiscent of a really top Zinfandel.  It all lingers on the fine-grain, noble finish. 400 cases imported

An extraordinary value, all aged in neutral French and American oak barrels for 12 months) is an exuberant, sexy, delicious red. Sweet blackberry and currant, licorice, smoke, and bacon-like flavors are top-class, a gorgeous texture, tremendous purity, and a long, heady finish.
exhibits fragrant dark berry characters balanced with mint aromas and hints of eucalypt.The palate is full flavoured, rich and round, yet displays elegance with fine tannins and a lingering finish.
Bright and tangy, with lime and green apple flavors that persist nicely on the lively finish.
dark berry, sweet spice, cedar, and tobacco
Firm and juicy, if a bit rustic. Layers peppermint-scented berry and earthy-spicy flavors nicely. Finishes with some refinement, but needs time. Best after 2007. 200 cases imported. HS
51% Zinfandel 25% Valdique 24% Cabernet Sauvignon

Deep garnet, showing nuances of dried strawberry, vanilla bean and mocha in the nose. The wine offers lavish flavors of cassis, black cherry, plum & espresso. A marriage of richness and restraint, the wine combines a lean, vibrant entry with profound mid-palate density. Silky tannins and a seamless balance enhance a long, unwavering finish accented by bittersweet chocolate and a hint of smoke.

Showing a lustrous dark ruby, the 2004 presents aromas of violets, cedar, black tea leaves, black pepper and brioche. A soft, creamy entry gives way to a concentrated mid-palate that expands in the mouth and lingers on the finish. Elements of cassis, toffee and cocoa round out the rich flavors of the wine. Intense fruit, bright acid and sturdy tannins promise resilience and longevity. The 2004 Opus One is composed of 86% Cabernet Sauvignon, 7% Merlot, 4% Petit Verdot, 2% Cabernet Franc, and 1% Malbec.

Aromatically complex, with enticing floral, perfumed fruit and spice, cedar and cigar box scents. Delivers a rich, complex core of earthy currant, mocha, exotic spice and fresh leather flavors. Tannins are well-integrated, with a long, vibrant, pleasantly earthy aftertaste.--1993 California Cabernet retrospective

Vintage Port - Quinta da Agua Alta
Notes: Muscular style. Closed and not giving much now, but this is a big, burly young Port with loads of violet and berry aromas and flavors and a seriously powerful backbone of tannin. Full-bodied. Long, mouthpuckering finish. Tannic attack. Best after 2008.

Tasting note: Clean, slightly citrus, Sauvignon Blanc characters. Touch lanolin. Interesting. Palate nice. Citrus characters on palate. Quite elegant. Acid slightly evident but a very well made, balanced style. Winner of a Blue-Gold Award and one of the Top 100 Wines in the Lighter Bodied Dry White Wines category at the Sydney International Wine Competition 2003. (Rodney Kemp, www.top100wines.com).  Food match: prawn salad with toasted pine nut dressing. (www.tizwine.com).  (Source:  Vintages, August 2003).  Robe jaune pâle claire. Nez minéral avec des nuances de fruits exotiques. Bouche droite et nerveuse, relativement pleine, élégante et incisive. Comme la flèche de Robin des Bois, lacidité fend lair et laisse une bouche franche et bien sèche. Très belle bouteille. *** Dégusté en juillet 2003.  (Source:  crusetsaveurs.com, September 2003).

Grape Tray: Dense and dark, with layers of cassis, ripe plum, blue-berry, black cherry extract and meaty wet clay flavors. Theres plenty of well-integrated toasty oak and round tannin providing structure through the intense, hot and lush finish.
drank in Montreal, 10/29/2005
Governor's Cup Winner
Serve with chocolate and candlelight.
12.0 % alc.;  Abruzzi region

The Capanna estate has been owned by the Cencioni family since 1957 and is situated to the north of Montalcino which has always been considered one of the best crus of Brunello. The farm is operated exclusively by the family and has been considered to be a point of reference for traditionalists. The wines are produced in the most traditional fashion and could even be considered rustic by some modern standards. Capanna Brunello di Montalcino is a very traditional Brunello, soft, suave and elegant. Due to its characterists, and its capacity to develop and improve for many years when bottled, this wine is now valued as one of the most exclusive Brunellos. Pretty and caressing, with aromas of chocolate, coffee, berry and cherry (Wine Spectator, 7/01). This wine is an excellent accompaniment to game, grilled red meat and matured cheeses. Its full-bodied taste also allows it to be enjoyed on its own.

Sagrantino di Montefalco 25 Anni is the result of passionate research and careful clonal selection of the best grapes of Sagrantino. It is a jubilee wine produced for the first time in 1993 to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the winery. Since then it has kept this name together with its unique character, power and elegance. Marco Caprai began managing the family winery in 1989 after studying enology and the enological history of their region. His goal was to revive the best indigenous varietals while experimenting with new varieties and techniques to best express the capabilities of their vineyard sites. In 2001, Marco was named "Best Italian Producer of the Year" by the Italian Sommelier Association for his success in respecting the long tradition of Italian wine-making while incorporating innovative research and technology practices.
Top 100 Wine of 2007: Elegant, dry and light- to medium-bodied, with concentrated peach, citrus and mineral flavors melding together. Stays focused through the lingering finish. 10,400 cases made.
12.5% alc; WS:  Concentrated, with plenty of roasted plum and meat flavors, and a smoky tinge. Tight finish filled with graphite notes. Drink now through 2009. 3,500 cases made.

Wine: Cotes du Rhone Domaine du Jongier

Notes: 13.0% alc;  Silver Medal: 2006 San Diego National Wine Competition;  Bronze Medal:  2007 San Francisco Chronicle Wine Competition, 2006 Florida State Fair International Wine Competition, 2006 Los Angeles County Fair

Wine: Whole Foods Market 365 Painted Horse California Merlot

Notes: I have served friends the brilliant 2001 Crianza (98% Tempranillo and 2% Graciano) just to prove what great wine can be purchased even with a weak dollar. It is a complex, elegant, deep ruby/purple-tinged offering boasting a sweet nose of lead pencil shavings, white chocolate, blackberries, and cherries. Medium-bodied with supple tannin as well as admirable structure, definition, and ripeness, it can be enjoyed now and over the next 5-8 years.

Beautiful kirsch and thyme on the nose, following through to flavors of cherry and herbs du Provence with a touch of white pepper. A clean, pretty wine possessing good definition, character and acidity with low tannin levels.

Notes: Bottled 1998
Deliciously ripe and complex, overflowing with layers of exotic spice, mineral, sage, currant and blackberry, and finishing with a burst of flavor. Tannins are well-integrated.Drink now through 2010.

ST: Saturated ruby. Black raspberry, cassis and strong torrefaction notes of roast coffee and bitter chocolate on the nose. Fleshy and concentrated, with excellent concentration and noteworthy finesse. This has the structure to age slowly and gracefully. Gives evidence of oak tannins, but the tannins are sweet.

Wine: Shiraz McLaren Vale The Dead Arm
Notes: This is a round, generous Shiraz that's packed with layers of flavor, offering ripe berry, plum, exotic spices and a touch of mint as the long finish unfurls. Can go decades in the cellar. Best after 2003. 6,500 cases made.

Top 100: 2009, Rank: 82.  Best Value:  Ripe and open-textured, this is impressive for the way it packs in the cherry, blackberry and raspberry flavors and keeps its foot on the gas pedal through the mineral-inflected finish. 5,000 cases imported

Varietal: Cabernet Sauvignon, Shiraz, Merlot, Cabernet Franc

Notes: ST: Deep dark red ruby. Perfumed, floral nose combines intense fruit aromas of raspberry, cherry and cassis with spice notes of clove and cinnamon. Very rustic, musky and reductive, with a meaty, somewhat cooked quality and moderate weight and richness. Spicy and rather evolved, with a background of vanillin and cedary oak. Finishes creamy and persistent, with dark prune and raisin fruit, and lingering hints of bitterness and alcoholic warmth.
wedding gift from stamper
Costco

Effusively peppery, with tremendous black and white pepper aromas that lace through the vigorous blackberry, currant and floral flavors, finishing with impressive vibrancy and length.  750 cases imported

The Muscat is even better than the Muscadelle (Tokay), offering a rose/amber color followed by notes of black tea. This sexy effort is the equivalent of liquid Viagra.  This wine is a great buy. The wine exhibits a light to medium amber color as well as an extraordinary bouquet of molasses, brown sugar, roasted nuts, and sweet fruitcake. Unctuously-textured as well as juicy, sweet yet fabulously fragrant and well-balanced in the mouth, this is a spectacular fortified wine to savor slowly after dinner. After bottling it neither improves nor declines, and is capable of lasting up to a decade.

There are two levels of quality - big and bigger. This is a decadent wine of extraordinary unctuosity, sweetness, and richness. This wine is between 6 and 10 years old, and is a viscous, super-sweet offering with a raisiny, pruny flavor.  The non-vintage Tokay possesses copious quantities of honeyed marmalade. It is spectacular, as well as under-valued. Once in the bottle, it changes slowly, and thus can be kept for two decades.

A rich, creamy Mosel kabinett, bursting with herb, vanilla custard and mineral aromas and flavors. It's supported by a lively acidity and ends with a tactile sensation. Drink now through 2012. (BS) WA Rich floral and slate aromas are found in the nose of the 2002 Riesling Kabinett Wehlener Sonnenuhr. Light to medium-bodied, softly-textured, as well as expressive, this is a flint, slate, and candied lime-flavored effort. It should be enjoyed over the next 4-5 years.

Very open, with a gossamer texture, and a slightly petillant character still, with fine slate aromas and flavors augmented by peach and spice notes. Focused and sleek as 2003 goes, this needs time. Best from 2006 through 2018. (BS)

Dense and packed with citrus notes, this kabinett has enough structure to keep it all focused and persistent, despite its opulent profile. Good grip on the finish, with a long aftertaste. Drink now through 2010. (BS)

Delicious pears and apples announce this chardonnay, followed by smooth, buttery oak. Rich flavors in the mouth show the ripeness of the 2000 vintage. This well-rounded wine was barrel fermented to match the crisp fruit to the oak. Aging the wine in the same barrels after fermentation greatly increased its complex flavors and textures. Enjoy it with creamy soups, light pastas and fish.

Vibrant entrance, raspberry plum and blueberry with anise-white pepper spice, nice barrel tones showing tobacco & nutty flavors. Round mouthfeel with velvety texture - rich and full with hints of mushroom and spice.

Drink now through 2007. Score - 91. (Harvey Steiman, www.winespectator.com, May 15, 2002)  Food match: rich seafood such as lobster with butter.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Pale straw color, with well-defined flavors of apple, citrus and biscuit. Very dry, fresh and palate-refreshing. Have it as an aperitif to get your evening started. $19.95 a bottle.  (Source:  Ottawa Life Magazine, March 12, 2002).

Varietal: Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot
Notes: Bronze medal winner at the 2001 Canadian Wine Awards.  Equuleus is Château des Charmes take on a Bordeaux blend, composed of 53% Cabernet Sauvignon, 34% Cabernet Franc and 13% Merlot, aged one year in French oak.  (Source:  Classics, Holiday 2002 Edition).  The 1998 Equuleus is a classically styled blend of 53% Cabernet Sauvignon, 32% Cabernet Franc and 15% Merlot. Equuleus is only produced in exceptional vintages and is notable for its age worthiness and concentration. Aged for one year in French Tronçais and Allier oak barrels, Equuleus is rich and full bodied with flavours of cassis and Dark Chocolate. Equuleus is the name of the "Little Horse" constellation, best seen when it rises in the night sky at harvest time every September. This equine symbol celebrates Château des Charmes' founder Paul-Michel Bosc's passion for Egyptian Arabian horses which are stabled at the Paul Bosc Estate, the family's home vineyard. (Source:  Producer's notes).

One of the best Cabernet Francs of the vintage, but needs time to develop. This is reserved and very firm. Very well extracted however with ripe almost dried blackberry fruit. Big, youthful, chewy tannin. Excellent Length.  (Source:  David Lawrason, Wine Access).  Medium deep ruby colour with aromas of raspberry, leather, vanilla, sweet herbs and mineral. Dry with ripe fruit with good silky tannins. Medium full-bodied with a medium long fruity and tannin finish.   Food match: roast beef with root vegetables, ratatouille.  (Source:  Vintages, April 2003)

As with the previous vintages this is crafted in a full and slightly sweet style. This wine has the smooth, tropical flavours of Californian Sauvignon. Very pretty, but lacks Sauvignon zest. The sweetness could work well with mildly spicy seafood or white meat dishes.  (Source:  Bill Munnelly, Best Bottles, Early Summer 2003).  It is smooth on the palate, exhibiting flavours of gooseberry and citrus fruit with an herbal note on the finish. A refreshing and easy drinking wine that is exceptional with food or as an aperitif.  This wine pairs very well with a number of dishes but makes an excellent match with herb chicken or cream pasta dishes.  (Source:  Producer).  Sweet aromas of honey, peach and pineapple stand-out. On the palate, there's a bounty of sweet fruit flavours that carry through the lingering finish. Don't let the sugary descriptors fool you, this is a dry wine best enjoyed with food.  (Source:  Vines Magazine, July - August 2003).
More merlot  and less Cabernet than the 2003, and not as heavy.

The 2001 Mission Hill Reserve Sauvignon Blanc offers an understated herbal aroma with bright citrus notes. This wine is every bit as delightful on the palate with its' rich flavours of gooseberry and green apple, balanced with a bright fresh acidity so indicitive of Okanagan wines. A wine of memorable fruit intensity and style.   2001 marked one of the warmest years ever in the Okanagan Valley. Monthly temperature variations were significant during the gowing season. April was quite cool, while May brought with it much warmer days, and a period of intense heat. August came in with beautiful hot weather, and it stayed above average for the rest of the summer. By the time harvest commenced, we had accumulated heat units far above the long-term average. Careful vineyard management continues to yield conservative crop levels with fruit size and colour being quite good. Vineyards planted six years ago are now mature and yielding well balanced, high quality fruit. Overall, indications suggest the quality of the 2001 harvest could be the best in a decade.  Grapes: 100% Sauvignon Blanc.  Vineyards: Osoyoos, Oliver.  Case Production: 1,200 cases.  Bronze Medal - Canadian Wine Awards, 11/2002, Winery of the Year - Canadian Wine Awards, 11/2001  (Source:  Mission Hill web site).

Wine: Pelee Island Cabernet Franc Ice Wine

Notes: The big winner from British Columbia is Gray Monk Pinot Gris 2001 ($15.90, No. 118638). This dry, unoaked white bursts forth with grapefruit, pear, citrus and a smoky-flinty quality.  (Source:  Globe and Mail, Beppi Crosariol, May 10, 2003).  Their signature wine, Pinot Gris means Gray Friar or Gray Monk when translated from Hungarian (Szurkebarat). The year 2002, when this wine was released in BC, was a very good one for Gray Monk. They celebrated the 20th anniversary of the winery, the 30th anniversary of the vineyard and 40th wedding anniversary of George and Trudy Heiss (owners of the winery). George Jr. is the full-time winemaker, though George Sr. is still very actively involved. At the 2002 Atlanta International Wine Challenge, Gray Monk was honoured with the 2002 Generations Award for the Family Winery of Distinction (North and Latin American). To qualify for the award, the winery must have had the best showing for its region at this annual competition. At the Challenge, they won three gold, two silver and three bronze medals.  Food match: pan-fried fresh lake fish.  (Source:  Vintages, May 10, 2003).
delicious mix of mild peachy, citrus fruit with just enough light butter, spice and honey. Medium bodied, slightly creamy with a firm, tidy finish. Good to very good length

Bronze Oakanagon Festival.  A rich, full flavoured wine, it has aromas of dark chocolate and dusky berry with a smooth yet subtle finish. The Stewart Family recommends trying the OVF Reserve with duck confit served on a bed of organic spring greens or filet mignon with a truffled mushroom ragout.
Betty's favorite
Released 2006 for 25th anniversary. Port-style wine

A repurchase of the same vintage we last released in our Pacific Northwest spotlight in January 2003.  Tasting note: Canadian Wine Awards Silver Medallist in 2001. Now settling into maturity with very fetching and complex ripe fruit, leather, cedar, mocha and herb aromas. Medium weight with very good extract and sweetness on the palate. Still shows Black Sage dusty tannin and earth on the finish. Excellent length. Now to 2006. Score - 90. (David Lawrason, Wine Access First In Line E-Report, Jan. 2003)  Food match: grilled portobello mushrooms.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

This classic blend of Cabernet and Merlot grapes was aged in small oak casks to maturity in our cellar to maturity. This full-bodied red wine is intense in color and possesses a depth of character imparting wonderful berry and cherry flavours
medal winner

The prestigious name Michel Torino is actually an amalgam of two winemaking families from Cafayate. In 1892 David and Salvador Michel planted the first vines and established Bodega La Rosa. When David married Gabriela Torino, the company known as Michel Torino was created. The soil of Cafayate Valley in Northwestern Argentina - loose, nitrogen-balanced, permeable sandy soil - is ideal for growing superior varietals. The combination of an altitude of 1700 metres above sea level, a climate of hot days and very cool nights, and carefully controlled irrigation adds up to the production of some great wines.  Our panel's tasting note: Deep ruby colour with aromas of tar, blackberry, bacon and cocoa. Dry, rich, ripe, plump with generous fruit and very supple tannins. Medium full-bodied with a very long finish.  Food match: barbecued salted beef.  (Source:  Vintages, April 5, 2003 release)

Wine: Santa Florentina Brut de Torrontes Champagne
Notes: Serve this wine with your turkey dinner and get everyone happier. This sparkling wine is more subtly scented than the still Torrontes from Etchart, of which I was so complementary above. Yet, it is still richly flavoured enough to take some spice in the food with which it is served. I liked it.  (Source:  www.winereviews.ca, October 2001)  Bright pale straw; quite brilliant. Dark and moody palate shot with fruit, toast, yeast notes and a hint of petrol. Mushroomy palate, lightly tart with vigorous mousse. Good body and length. Very nice. A tad serious.  (Source:  Frugal Oenophile, October 2001).
purchased in Rio De Janeiro
Deep colour with a hint of liquorice and big, jammy, peppery fruit. Great length, full-bored and generous. Rich, intense, spicy this is the absolute best partner for beef.

Este vino recibió una elaboración en tinto clásica, en donde se obtuvo el excelente  color que posee de tono rojo vivo.  En boca se presenta equilibrado con una concentración tánica de calidad que aportan un muy buen volumen en boca. Debido a esto, es un vino de personalidad y de gran aceptación entre los consumidores .

Medium straw colour; delicate floral, citrus and peach aromas; peachy and citrusy flavours; light-bodied, medium dry with crisp acidity

This wine originates from the limestone-rich clay till soils of our Cave Spring Vineyard, located on a terrace of the Niagara Escarpment overlooking Lake Ontario, and made from our lowest yielding vines. Minimally filtered, it may throw sediment with bottle age. Decant if necessary.  Produced from 6 to 8 year old vines at Cave Spring Vineyard.   Approachable in its youth, it should continue to develop favourably for 8 to 10 years.  Food matches:  Roast of beef, duck or venison; rack of lamb or grilled lamb chops with ratatouille; peppercorn steak; dry, well-aged cheeses such as Cheddar or Parmesan.  (Cave Spring web site, September 5, 2005).

Bone dry and a touch austere, with harmonious peach, citrus and mineral flavors and a lively backbone. Light-bodied yet powerful, with a lingering finish. Drink now through 2004. 2,300 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator web site, 2002).  'CSV' is the designation for Cave Spring's top-end wines.  Tasting note: The second vintage of Cave Spring's premium Riesling is an estate-grown charmer (from 20-plus year old vines). This vibrant white features fleshy peach flavours and a rapier-like lemon zest acidity that balances the hint of residual sugar on the palate. The concentrated young wine benefits from some deep leesy and complex mineral notes - it's a bit funky when you first pull the cork, fear not. Offering good value for the price, it deserves to be served with stir-fries and salads or, better yet, salmon. Put one away until 2010 and amaze your friends and yourself with the complexity of this powerful white. Score - **** (out of 5). (Christopher Waters, Vines, July/Aug. 2002)  Niagara has also been having a great run with riesling, and there's an excellent example today in Cave Spring Riesling CSV 2000 ($25, No. 566026). Light- to medium-bodied and dry, it's ripe with flavours of pear and peach and a hint of mineral. Let this wine breathe a little after you open it to blow off a slightly burnt, sulphur-like quality that may have come from bottling. It's harmless and should disappear quickly.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe & Mail, June 7, 2003).

64% Cabernet Franc, 27% Cabernet Sauvignon and 9% Pinot Noir. Yield 3.5 tonnes/acre. After crushing, varietals remained on the skins for up to 24 hours, after which juice was bled and fermented dry. A dry style of rose which is crisp and refreshing with aromas and flavours of green herbs, pepper, spice and fresh berries. Best consumed within the first 3 years. Food matches: Grilled vegetable salads; traditional antipasti; medium cheeses; cold cuts; barbecue turkey or pork.  (Source:  Producer)

Vista: Rojo profundo, tonos violáceos que denotan juventud. Brillante, intenso y limpido. Nariz: Aromas a grosella, especias y pimenta. Notas de vanilla, aportadas por su paso por roble. En boca: Elegante y armonioso. Taninos suaves y buen final de boca. Gastronomía: Ideal para acompañar carnes rojas, pastas con salsas intensas, cerdo y quesos maduros.

A massive red, almost brooding in depth, that shows what Ontario's warmest wine region can deliver, especially in a great year like 2002. The dark ripe fruit is only part of the picture, because this shows great equilibrium in tannins and acidity. Overall, a stylish and bold Merlot at a great price. Drink it now with a hunk of medium-rare red meat, or stash it away for another five to ten years. (RP)

The purple-colored 2007 Catena Malbec spent 12 months in 35% new French and American oak. The nose reveals balsam wood, vanilla, mocha, cassis, and black cherry. Plush on the palate, this medium-bodied Malbec has layered, spicy flavors, with a touch of tobacco and leather making an appearance. Balanced and lengthy, it will evolve for 2-3 years and offer prime drinking from 2011 to 2019. Score - 91+. (Jay Miller, www.erobertparker.com, Aug. 2009)

cor: vermelho rubi com tons violáceos. aroma: vinho de corpo médio, com aromas a ameixas maduras e com um fundo leve de especiarias. paladar: possui taninos doces e suaves, e sabores concentrados a frutas vermelhas. um vinho bastante agradável e atrativo.
verm intenso, aromas de surpreendente intensidade, toques de incenso, framboesa, mel e fumaça. Taninos poderosos, longa duração, sensação de frutas e couro novo.

Viña MontGras is the brainchild of the Gras brothers, Hernan and Eduardo, and Christián Hartwig, brother of Alejandro Hartwig of the neighbouring Santa Laura winery (Alejandros Laura Hartwig line of wines has appeared at Vintages in the recent past).  For most wine consumers, Chile has been a source of easy drinking, inexpensive, fruity wines. However, todays consumer demands more than cheap and cheerful. MontGras founders shared vision is to create a Chilean wine that gives a new definition to quality. For example, their grapes are all hand-picked and table-sorted to select the best fruit. Within the winery, Hernan Gras design ensures that all the juices are transferred by gravity-feed and do not have to be mechanically pumped from crusher/destemmer to fermenting tanks, or from fermenting tanks to cold storage containers. (A fascinating piece of trivia is that Hernan Gras was the winemaker for T.G. Bright in Niagara for many years).  The whole winery is designed using the most modern of techniques. From the scientific analysis used to choose the vineyard locations, to the reshaping of the landscape to best assist the grapes growth; from the most current trellising methods, to the most up-to-date equipment, MontGras has spared no expense.   MontGras stresses the differences in terroir and seeks to express them in all of their wines. As such, each wine is made from certain blocks within specific vineyards. In the case of their Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon/Syrah (976787), all the grapes come from their San José Vineyards in the Colchagua Valley. The Cabernet Sauvignon is matured for 12 months in French and American oak while the Syrah is matured in stainless steel. Their thinking is that the Cabernet Sauvignon gives the body and structure to the wine, especially to the beginning and the end, while the unoaked, fruit-driven Syrah fills it out, especially in the centre.  Though they plan to maintain their customer-friendly, hands-on style and accessible prices, Viña MontGras still continues to develop wines of increasing levels of quality and complexity. They now produce five levels of wine: their entry level Estate, their mid-range Reserva, their upper mid-range Quatro (their four grape Bordeaux blend), their premium Limited Edition (see their Syrah, 977777) and their ultra premium Ninquén (pronounced nin-ken, meaning plateau on a mountain) from a unique high-elevation mountain vineyard.   Viña MontGras combination of artisanal attitude and scientific approach will continue to redefine Chilean wine.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Valtellina is the most northerly winegrowing region in Italy. In fact, at one point in its history it almost became a part of Switzerland. Though technically part of the larger Lombardy appellation, it is a region almost unto itself. The three major zones of Lombardy: Valtellina, Oltrepò Pavese and Franciacorta are stylistically quite unique with no connection among them except geography. Valtellina, for example, is known for their interpretation of the Nebbiolo grape that in some hands can rival quality wines from Piedmont's Barolo and Barbaresco. And like these Piedmont wines, Valtellina usually benefits from serious cellar time. Consider cellaring for 3-4 years.  (Source:  Vintages web site, August 2004).

Gavi was elevated to DOCG status in 1998. Made with the Cortese grape  considered indigenous to Piedmont  Gavi is highly prized for its aromatic citrus, pit fruit and mineral tones. Try with vegetarian fare or shellfish.  (Source:  Vintages - February 2002 Release)

Spinelli 'Terra d'Aligi' Montepulciano d'Abruzzo is made entirely from the Montepulciano grape. Centuries ago, wool traders from Tuscany are believed to have brought Sangiovese vines to Abruzzi. According to this legend, Montepulciano is really Sangiovese that has adapted to the local climate and growing conditions of the region of Abruzzi. 'Terra d'Aligi' is one of our most successful Montepulciano d'Abruzzos we have ever released. With its long, elegant bottle and, of course, superior contents within, it has always been a crowd-pleaser.  Food match: hamburgers, roasted vegetables, pasta with meat sauce, grilled steak. In 1855, Vittorio degli Albizi returned from Burgundy to manage his familys property (todays Marchesi de Frescobaldi) in the Pomino region of Tuscany. Aged for 15 months in French oak barriques, Frescobaldis Pomino Rosso is a medium- to full-bodied blend of Sangiovese and Pinot Noir with a hint of Merlot and Malvasia Rossa. Raspberry and mineral aromas carry through from the nose to the palate, tannins are notably silky and the finish is fresh and juicy. This wine will go on improving for four more years but is drinking well now, a lovely partner for bistecca alla Fiorentina (Florentine T-bone steak.)  (Source:  Vintages, September 2002 wine of the month).

Varietal: Nerello Mascalese, Nerello Cappuccio, Gaglioppo and Greco Nero
Notes: La Calabre, tout au sud de l'Italie, produit surtout du vin de table [4% de DOC seulement], mais un producteur se démarque: Cantina Lento à Lamezia Terme, dont le cabernet sauvignon, Federico II, m'a laissé un très bon souvenir. Le Lamezia rosso Riserva 1996, fait de cépages locaux, est arrivé à la LCBO en septembre dernier. Voici ce que ça donne: Bonne intensité aromatique, avec des fruits cuits, du cèdre, du tabac et un peu de caoutchouc. Peu acide et peu tannique, il n'est pas très corsé mais tout de même assez rond. La finale est vanillée avec une bonne longueur. Pas un vin de garde, il plaira à ceux qui recherchent un vin rond, peu tannique et prêt à boire. 13/20. 23 octobre 2002  (Source:    Alain Brault, www.vinquebec.com).  Lento's Lamezia Riserva is an excellent example of the blender's art at work at a regional level. The grapes used here are quite uncommon: Nerello Mascalese, a dark, spicy, perfumed red grape; Nerello Cappuccio, a good blending grape for filling out the middle; Gaglioppo, adding a tannic grip to blends; and Greco Nero, another excellent blending grape which adds an acid crispness. The finished wines are designed to be enjoyed with local cuisine.  Food match: eggplant parmigiana (a local Calabrian specialty), spicy Italian sausage.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Tasting note: Medium straw with aromas of muscat, red grapefruit, macintosh apples. Off-dry, fruity, ripe and round. Soft, pleasing and nicely balanced flavours and finish. (David Churchill, Vintages, June 2003).  Food match: cream cheese sandwiches.  (Source:  Vintages, August 2003).

Complex aromas of blackberries, tobacco, spices and black licorice are alluring in this full-bodied claret, with a solid core of fruit and silky tannins. Long, caressing finish. Superfine, well-structured. Wine of the vintage. Best after 2006. 22,500 cases made. (JS)
Rich and lovely wine for the vintage. Aromas of berries, herbs and tobacco. Medium- to full-bodied, with velvety tannins and a medium finish. Soft and delicious. Best after 2004. (JS)(WS)

Full bodied, deep purple towards garnet wine has tempting black cherry, cassis and wild berry flavors and aromas, all with generous hints of spicy eucalyptus and a long finish. Elegant and tempting now but the wine will be at its best only from about 2005 - 2020. Score 93.

[Wine Spectator 03/31/2003] - Beautiful tobacco, berry, cedar and plum aromas in this one.  Full-bodied, yet very fine and reserved, with silky tannins and a medium finish.  I still prefer the 1998, but this is very, very fine indeed.  A Haut-Brion with lots of finesse.  Best after 2010.

[Wine Spectator 03/31/2003] - Collectibles - A young wine that electrifies every taste bud in your mouth.  Compacted aromas of crushed currants and minerals, with roses and lilacs.  Full-bodied, with masses of silky, refined tannins and a finish that lasts for minutes.  Stunning.  Best Latour since 1990.  Best after 2012.  14165 cases made.
Costco; Lots of tobacco, berry, currants and cedar character. Medium- to full-bodied, with good tannins and a fresh finish. Too good for a second wine.

In 2001, Falesco's winemaker Riccardo Cotarella was named the Winemaker of the Year in Wine Enthusiast. Gambero Rosso magazine extended the same honour to him in 2000.  Tasting note: One of the great values in the world continues to be the blend of equal parts Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Sangiovese called Vitiano. The 2001, aged three months in wood before being bottled, is a deep ruby-colored effort with vivid aromas of black cherries, new saddle leather, dried Provencal herbs, spice box, and licorice. It is more tightly-knit, and plays it closer to the vest than the more opulent 2000 Vitiano. The 2001 possesses lovely fruit, outstanding purity, and a long, spicy finish with considerable elegance as well as staying power. For $10 US (approximately $15.00 CDN at a conversion rate of 1.50), this remains one of the most remarkable wine values in the world. Drink it over the next 2-3 years. (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com, Dec. 2002)  Food match: grilled tuna.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).  There's a lovely softness and richness to this red. Medium- to full-bodied, with round and caressing tannins, and a long, plummy, chocolate and meaty finish. A fantastic bottle for the money. Best Vitiano I have ever had. Sangiovese, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot. Drink now. 200,000 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, May 31, 2003).

I read an amusing line in a cookbook recently. "What do you call a meal without wine?" The answer: "Breakfast."  But there's no need to ban wine from the morning table. Not when there's moscato d'Asti, a product diehard wine drinkers jokingly call "the perfect breakfast wine."  Moscato d'Asti must be one of the world's most misunderstood wines, mainly because it is regularly confused with Asti spumante, the popular sparkling wine of Italy. Moscato, which comes from the same region in the northwest part of the country called Piedmont, is much more distinguished and harder to come by.  It's not sparkling but rather gently effervescent, a quality Italians call frizzante (fizzy). In fact, the bubbles are so gentle that the wine comes sealed with a regular cork, not the mushroom-shaped champagne top. Generally made in tiny batches by small producers, it's more individual than Asti spumante, which typically is produced in bulk and blended from widespread vineyards.  Moscato also is lighter in alcohol, typically 5.5 per cent versus 7 to 10 per cent for Asti. That's why you could conceivably drink it with your Sunday pancakes.  The flavour is extraordinary. Made from the moscato bianco grape, it delivers a wonderfully musky flavour, akin to fresh table grapes. There's always some residual sugar in the wine, enough to place it in the dessert category, and it's always served cold. Perfect with biscotti, it's especially captivating with fresh fruit, notably strawberries, another fact that no doubt helped give rise to the breakfast-bracer reputation.  Because the light bubbles and zesty acid give it a clean lift, the Italians also enjoy this delicate white as an apéritif or light summer refresher. One wise critic once called it the ideal summer wine.  There's a very good example being released today in Ontario Vintages stores. It's called Villa Giada Ceirole Moscato d'Asti 2001 ($16.95, product No. 705897). Made in a modern style with exceptionally low alcohol (4.5 per cent), it's captivatingly fragrant, with a delicious hint of peach. Don't put it in the cellar, though. These wines are best enjoyed at their height of freshness.  (Source:  Globe and Mail, Beppi Crosariol, May 10, 2003). Light to medium-bodied with a lingering finish. Food match: coffee-flavoured ice cream with fresh strawberries.  Tasted in October 2002.  (Source:  Vintages, May 10, 2003).

RP:  he 2000 Santa Cruz de Artazuri (600 cases) is 100% Grenache from a high altitude, 100+ year old vineyard with gravelly/chalky soils. The wine was aged 8-10 months in large French demi-muids, and bottled with minimal clarification. It elicited three "wow's" from me when tasted. It boasts a gorgeous perfume of black raspberry liqueur mixed with cherries, blackberries, minerals, and licorice. Although restrained, it cannot conceal its full body, opulence, richness, and overall purity. This sexy, amazing red tastes like a $50-$60 wine. Enjoy it over the next decade. This debut offering from Artazuri, a project of Juan-Carlos Lopez de la Call, the force behind Rioja's great Bodegas Artadi, is worth buying by the case.

Te 2001 Vinas de Gain (100% Tempranillo) is a fabulous effort for the price (one of the best buys in the marketplace). Aged in French oak casks (about 40% new) for 12-14 months, it boasts a deep purple color to the rim as well as a per-fume of raspberries, blackberries, crushed stones, and white flowers. With extraordinary precision, definition, and finesse, great elegance, wonderful sweetness, me-dium body, and a gorgeously textured finish, it caresses the palate, offering considerable personality and overall symmetry. It will drink beautifully for 7-8 years.

Solomon calls Montsant "the next Priorat," no careless boast as his wife is the owner of Priorat's Clos Erasmus. This high altitude vineyard has produced an opaque ruby/purple-colored wine with exceptional density, as well as gorgeously pure blackberry and blueberry fruit intermixed with minerals and a hint of French oak.This blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 40% Grenache (from 70-year old vines), and 10% Carignan was aged completely in French oak before being bottled unfined and unfiltered. It is a remarkable value from importer Eric Solomon. There are 2,000 cases available in the United States.

50% syrah, 50% grenache; This chateau is located in the southern Rhone, in the village of Ventoux. The wine is complex and medium-to-full bodied with plenty of dark red fruit in the nose and on the palate. Medium oak and balanced tannins provide a nice finish.

I tasted this wine last May and it was a knockout! Filled with ripe berry fruit and cassis, this red from Valencia has a wild and brambly quality about it. Enjoy this wine with a grilled pork loin seasoned with a spicy dry rub. Parker says: The debut vintage from a producer whom Eric Solomon feels is a future star, this blend of 40% Tempranillo, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Mourvedre, and 10% Mando (a local grape) was aged 4-6 months in barrel. Its opaque purple color is followed by sumptuous aromas of peppery sweet black fruits, licorice, scorched earth, and red as well as black currants. With tremendous purity, intensity, texture, and fruit, it is a Spanish red to buy by the trunkful. A great bargain, it will drink well for 2-3 years.

Robert Parker of the Wine Advocate calls the 2002 Garnacha perhaps the greatest discovery of his 25-year career and the greatest wine value he has ever tasted!  He describes it as "Deep ruby/purple-colored, with a gorgeous nose of kirsch liqueur intermixed with melted licorice and white flowers ... deep, medium to full-bodied, fruit-driven, sumptuously-textured, (and) loaded."  91 points.

#1; COLOR-cloudy dark; NOSE-this is interesting; mustiness; cherry & raw hamburger meat w/ pepper; fortified PORT action on the finish (caramel, butterscotch); and a Kirsch component; TASTE-one of the most massively rich, explosive cherry pie w/ hints of bacon; secondary flavors of bacon & liver fat; big cherry explosion; hints of white & black pepper; oregano action on the mid-palate; as smooth & complex a fruit bomb as I've had in a long time; an imaginary blend of Chateau Beaucastel CDP blended w/ a rich & elegant Colgin Cabernet; a hedonistic Old World, structured & balanced fruit bomb lovely & massive wine; little Frangelico/ Baily's component on the very tail-end (& a little heat too); the perfect harmony between Old & New World; I love this wine; one of the best CDP's I've ever had w/ a little CaliCab Vanilla-love; a monstrous effort; still tasting the cherry along w/ a little secondary lavender; GV-95  "Another up-and-coming but little known estate from the Cotes du Ventoux, this could well be one of the next hot cult wines from Provence given the quality of this release. A blend of 75% Grenache and the rest Syrah, Carignan, and Cinsault, the wine has a deep ruby/purple color, a natural savory mouthfeel with terrific ripeness, soft but noticeable tannins in addition to plenty of Provencal herbs, pepper, and meaty black cherry and black currant fruit notes. The wine is a beauty, and should age nicely for 5-6 years." RP

Notes: RP:  Obviously Christian Canute is not shy about his pricing procedure, as reflected in the 2000 Shiraz Black Guts. Made from microscopic yields of .5 - 2 tons of fruit per acre, aged 30 months in a combination of French and American barrels, and bottled without filtration, it is an ambitious, serious Shiraz that stands out as one of this challenging vintages top efforts. An artisinal style is apparent in the wines controversial, kinky bouquet of flowers intermixed with blackberries, rhubarb, pepper, and licorice. While deep, full-bodied, and impressive, its singular style will not be enjoyed by everybody. Drink it over the next 10-15 years.

Produced from 26-year old vines and aged in French oak (80% new), the 2002 Shiraz G. A. M. reveals tremendous fruit purity, but it does not yet reveal secondary nuances. The inky blue/purple color is accompanied by aromas of ink, camphor, graphite, blackberries, and blueberries. While it possesses tremendous purity as well as an enormous full-bodied texture, it is neither heavy nor overbearing. This stunning Shiraz may be even better than the 2002 Savitar. Time will tell. Barrel samples of three 2002s revealed tremendous potential in what appears to be the finest efforts Mitolo has yet produced. There are 300-400 cases of each, and all three are scheduled to be bottled in October. Kudos to young importer (31 years old!) Ben Hammerschlag for unearthing these potential superstars.

From vineyards in North Coast County, this Cabernet holds a rich, dark and purple color that leads to a wonderfully enticing aroma of blackberry. It has delicious fruit notes of ripe blackberry, big cherries which ends with a smooth and spicy finish. A bright, lively and balanced Cab that will accompany prime rib, tri-tip steaks, and babyback ribs.

Staete Landt is owned by the dynamic Dutch expatriate couple Ruud Maasdam and Dorien Vermaas. On two visits to Toronto last year, their enthusiasm was infectious. They happily talked about their small, carefully considered property, explaining the origins of their name while showing maps of their land and sampling their wines. Staete Landt was the first European name given to New Zealand by the Dutch explorer Abel Tasman in 1642. It means 'land discovered in honour of the Governors (Staete) of the Dutch Republic'. Tasman also discovered Tasmania, Fiji and Tonga. The 2001 vintage represents Staete Landt's second vintage. If this is the shape of things to come, they have a very good future indeed.  Vintages tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of gooseberry, passion fruit and lime. Dry, very fresh and clean with expressive fruit and citrus aroma replays on the palate. Medium full-bodied with a long, crisp finish. Very good representation of the classic Kiwi style of Sauvignon Blanc. (David Churchill, Oct. 2002)  Food match: lightly spiced calamari, crab cakes.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).  Comments on 2000 vintage:  Crisp, zingy and remarkably focused, this shows lots of green apple, lime and papaya aromas and flavors; balances sweet flavors with lively acidity on the long finish. Debut vintage for the U.S. 2,000 cases made.  (Wine Spectator, May 31, 2001).

Winery: R. Lopez de Heredia Viña Tondonia
Notes: Delicate and ethereal. A fine example of traditional white Rioja, with nutty honey and dried pear flavors that linger endlessly on the finish. Not a powerhouse, but rich with flavor and finesse. Drink now. 5,000 cases made. Rated as "Highly Recommended"  (Source:  Wine Spectator, November 30, 2001).  The current winemaker at R. Lopez de Heredia Viña Tondonia is Maria Jose Lopez de Heredia. This wine was made before Maria's time but it is a fine example of Viña Tondonia's past. The wine is made exclusively with the Viura grape (a.k.a. Macabeo). It spends at least two years in barrel and then another period in bottle before release.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium gold colour with aromas of lemon zest, binned apples and toasty oak. Dry, forceful, toasty/fruity. Full-bodied with a very long finish. (Oct. 2002)  Food match: rich fish, such as salmon with a lime/dill sauce.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).
K&L wine club January selection
100% tempranillo matured 18 months in american oak casks

The wine is made with 100% Tinto Fino, the local name for Tempranillo. Cigales is a wine zone in north/northwest Spain. Traditionally, they have been known for their rosés from Tinto Fino and Garnacha, but increasingly quality producers, such as Valdelosfrailes, are making strides with dry red wines.  Tasting Note:  Colour: intense cherry, deep red edge. The nose is very complex, with notes of mature fruit (blackberry, raspberry) and a lightly spiced background. The palate is meaty and flavourful denoting a great personality. Aftertaste long and intense. (Epicure, Jan. 2003)

Fase visual: Color amarillo pálido verdoso, limpio y brillante. Fase olfativa: En nariz es potente y muy afrutado. Fase gustativa: Paladar fresco, equilibrado y goloso, con un delicado final de boca muy característico, que recuerda a los verdejos de los que procede. Conviene tomarlo muy frío, no sólo acompañando platos de pescado, marisco, etc.., sino también como aperitivo.

Remarkably fresh in texture, but maturing in flavor, this red shows plum, tobacco, lead pencil and spice flavors over firm, well-integrated tannins. Impressive concentration; traditional style. Drink now through 2009. 9,000 cases made.  (Wine Spectator, November 30, 2004).  Medium deep garnet colour with aromas of mushroom, mocha, berry, leather and marzipan. It is dry, intense, supple and elegant. Medium full-bodied with a long, lush finish. (Vintages panel, Nov. 2003)

Our panel's tasting note: No tilting at windmills required with this mellow, easy drinking La Mancha wine. Medium ruby in colour with aromas of strawberry jam, cocoa and a lot of toasty oak. Dry, velvety and smooth. (Sept. 2002)  Food match: barbecued hamburgers or portobello mushroom burgers.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Comments on 1998 vintage:  Juicy plum and chocolate aromas and flavors are alluring in this lively, firm red that's ripe and clean. An affordable chance to try Tempranillo if you've hesitated before. Drink now through 2004. 100,000 cases made.  Rated 'Best Buy'.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, November 15, 2001).

aromas of spices and mature red fruits. In the mouth, round tannins with powerful complexity. A rich unctuous wine with notes of mature plums, hazelnuts and red fruits. A very rich wine full of harmony and balance

The dense ruby/purple-colored 2001 Rioja Reserva exhibits a sweet, intense nose of melted licorice, road tar, truffles, black currants, cherries, and hints of smoky, toasty oak. Dense and medium to full-bodied, with moderately high tannin, it should be cellared for 1-2 years, and drunk over the following decade. This large 72-acre estates youngest vines are 33 years old, followed by a parcel of 45-year old vines, and two large parcels of 73 and 96-year old vines. The wine is kept one year in tank and then moved to small barrels where it spends another two years before being bottled unfined and unfiltered. (WA) WS Generous and well-structured. Plum, licorice, toast and spice flavors mingle over firm, ripe tannins in this modern red. It's balanced for food. Drink now through 2009. 500 cases imported

'Rodan' Reserva is a blend of 90% Tempranillo and 10% Mazuelo. It is aged two years in new American barriques, and then given a further two years in bottles, before being released.  Food match: braised beef dishes.  (Vintages, December 2004).

This distinctive red is graceful on the palate, but has an intensity that amplifies and focuses its ripe fruit and toasty oak flavors, driving them across the palate and into the long, long finish. It's not showy, but the longer you linger, the more it delivers. Drink now through 2015. 7,600 cases made. (TM)

This wine is still a baby, needing a decant or some time in the cellar to show everything it has to offer.

This dark ruby Pinot Noir has rich aromas of ripe blackberries, cinnamon, allspice, cedar and roasted coffee. The equally compelling flavors consist of raspberries, currants and a bit of a wild fruit or a briary component that gives an overall lift to the palate.  Although the 2004 vintage was a bit warmer and drier than we typically see, the altitude of this vineyard helped to maintain the bright acidity that keeps this wine balanced.  Although there is still some mouth coating tannins, this wine is drinking well now and should improve for 5 to 8 years
Firm, with red currant, cedar and wild berry tones that finish with solid tannins and herb notes. Drink now through 2007. 22,000 cases made.

"Powerful, dense nose of dark plum, smoke and a hint of blackstrap, with flavors to match. This is a robust, deeply colored and intense, tarry red that is made in a no-holds-barred style. Finish is filled with Bourbon and spice. Best from 2006 through 2010."

Medium to full-bodied, rich, broad, pure, and beautifully textured, it is a serious Pinot Noir to drink now and over the next 5-7 years.

Weingut Sander does not vineyard designate their wines even though they are allowed to. The regulations for organic farming in Rheinhessen are set and controlled by the NATURLAND company. Robert Parker, Jr., The Wine Advocate #161 10/31/05 "I continue to be shocked by encounters with top-flight Merlot from Australia (it doesnt happen that often). Cranefords 2004 Merlot, a knock-out effort from the Barossa that spent 16 months in French oak, exhibits a dark ruby/purple color in addition to rich aromas of berry fruit, roasted coffee, chocolate, and subtle herbs. This fleshy, voluptuously-textured, hedonistic Merlot will provide immense pleasure over th next 5-6 years."
Grape Tray; Tremendous balance, depth, elegance, richness and flavor, offering layers of ripe fig, pear, and honeysuckle, and turning smooth and creamy, giving it a wonderful aftertaste.  540 cases
let this age as 2000 was $150

This classically styled Rioja Reserva is a silky, delicious and affordably-priced red that will pair well with a wide range of seasonal fare. It comes from traditional Rioja producer Bodegas Riojanas, which was founded in 1890 in the town of Cenicero in the Rioja Alta sub-zone, midway between Haro and Logroño. Although the winery sources grapes from many highly regarded areas of Rioja Alta and some in Rioja Alavesa, Monte Real is made primarily from Cenicero grapes, which help give the wine its distinctive character. The 2000 Reserva is a great example of a well-made classic showing its quality, appeal and sheer drinkability among a sea of more heavily weighted modern wines. It is a clear, rich ruby red color with a complex nose of tangy cherry, briary blackberry, dried plum and wild strawberry. On the palate the attack is silky and smooth with nice grip. Tangy dried cherry flavors mingle with warm oak tones and subtle touches of licorice, damp black soil and limestone. The medium to full body is buoyed by good acidity and the overall impression is lively and elegant with a smooth, almost chewy cherry finish. This is quintessential Rioja with its own distinctive character of place. Serve with just about anything from tapas starters or rich, meaty fish dishes through grilled steak.

76% Zinfandel, 16% Petite Sirah, 8% Merlot Gobs of boysenberry and blackberry flavors greet you up front. Chocolate covered raisins, dusty mocha and bittersweet chocolate envelops your mid-palate with a hint of licorice. Kitchen spices of cinnamon, nutmeg, black pepper and burnt caramel round out the finish. This is an elegant monster of a Zin, with well-integrated tannins and a finish that lingers forever

Gorgeous aromas of white peach and lychee fruit. Delicate apricot flavors envelop your palate up front, with a hint of orange blossoms on the mid-palate. This is a full-bodied wine, but with clean bracing acidity to make it stand up to any meal. Mineral components and crisp green apple are emphasized on the long finish. This is a very well-balanced wine.

Varietal: 75% Merlot, 14% Cabernet Sauvignon, 3% Petite Verdot, 3% Malbec, 3% Cabernet Franc
Notes: This seductive Meritage greets you with aromas of rose petals followed by cassis, plum and blackberry and gorgeous, toasty French oak. Kitchen box spices of cloves and nutmeg start off on the palate with a hint of anise unfolding into a velvety textured medley of wild boysenberries and smokey notes. Wrapped up with silky tannins accompanied by incredible harmony and elegance, this a soft, yet complex and opulent wine.

Brilliant stone fruits-white peach, honeysuckle and orange blossom. Toasty vanilla tantalizes your mid-palate with fine beading. This medium-bodied sparkler has lots of green apple, pear and citrus flavors that evolve with a hint of caramel and biscotti. Its elegant and crisp with a slightly spicy finish

ncredible blueberry essence on the nose of this Syrah. The pallet continues to unfold offering hints of dark chocolate and dusty earth. It evolves into the mid-palate with plums, black fruits and smoky, leathery tannins that move into a velvety smooth finish. This is an elegant and full-bodied Syrah. .

Lively and bright on the nose with apples, peaches, mangos and fresh acidity surrounded in smokey oak tones. It is full bodied and very fleshy on the palate, with excellent depth of flavor, and a long, mildly oakey finish. It tastes of tropical fruit, peach, lemon, toasted oak, and baked bread.

Taste: This sumptuous wine greets you up front with toasty oak notes lifted with vibrant tropical banana and guava fruit. On the palate shes got brilliant fruit, perfectly integrated new French oak, and a kiss of butter cream again lifted with pretty minerality and that patented Russian River Valley acidity. Notes of citrus blossom, tropical fruit, and vanilla cream increase in intensity as the finish rolls in like a wave and increases in intensity. This wine is defined by a beautiful sense of elegance and fabulous overall structure.

Gorgeous stuff, it practically radiates a range of aromas and flavors, balancing its ripe cherry, blackberry and plum fruit with hints of minerals and sweet spices that make the finish sing for days. Tempting to drink, but just wait. Best from 2008 through 2020. 5,200 cases made.

Enjoy it with spicy sausages, cured meats and many grilled meats such as chicken, beef and lamb. Don't forget your roasted vegetables on the side. Drink now or within 3-5 years.

expressing the wonderful dusty raspberry and blackberry flavors, which exemplify the Oakley terrior, with additional characteristics of white pepper, coffee and chocolate nuances. Aging in new and used wood has lent this wine a subtle vanilla quality that compliments the explosive fruit notes.

And now for something completely different. Here is a Kiwi SB that has a touch of restraint and finesse. All the elements are there in spades, herbaceousness, gooseberry, passion fruit and citrus, but they are subdued in a charming and inviting manner. If you like aspects of typical Sauvignon Blanc, but find them overpowering (as many do) then I highly recommend this to you. Pair with all the usual suspects - Goat's cheese, grilled asparagus, Greek salad - and luxuriate in this fine wine. Well priced, as well. (VH)

The Sicilian estate of Morgante employs the brilliant Umbrian winemaking consultant, Riccardo Cotarella, to fashion this cuvee from the indigenous Nero d'Avola grape. Aged four months in French oak, it boasts a beautiful dense ruby/purple hue as well as aromas of scorched earth, black cherries, blackberries, charcoal, and graphite, full-bodied, powerful, pure flavors, and a long, heady finish. This substantial beauty should be enjoyed over the next 1-2 years."

ow yields and a long cool autumn period combined to produce a vintage in which our 2006 Te Tera Sauvignon Blanc shows intense varietal character and flavour. The extended ripening period allowed the grapes to retain their natural acidity whilst concentrating flavours enabling us to make a wine we believe exhibits some of the best elements of New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc. This wine displays a melding of herbaceous and tropical characters with gooseberry, passionfruit, tropical lychee and citrus notes on the nose with a palate that dispalys complexity of fruit, length and intensity.

"The technical director for Rejadorada, Jose Ignacio 'Chencho', is the chief oenologist for all of the bodegas within the Denominacion de Origens in the province of Castilla y Leon. He is a well-respected figure in the Spanish wine industry, and for his vast knowledge of the Toro region. For this reason, the investors from Vega Sicilia consulted with 'Chencho' to find the best vines and soil for their newest project Pintia. With the pedigree of old vine fruit and sound enology, Bodega Rejadorada produces wines with great intensity and finesse. The power and elegance have been said to be similar to some of the best wines from Priorat. Rejadorada captures the true essence of the Toro region. The Rejadorada Tinto Roble offers sweet aromas of black cherries and currants. Plenty of fruit in the mouth - loaded with blackberries, black cherries and currants - this beginning and middle is followed by a finish of licorice, smoke, and earth. Quite a story. Certainly not a short one." -Importer #2; COLOR-darker; NOSE-smoked ham w/ cherry sauce on it; TASTE-more popular flavor profile for US, very dry, totally integrated, more lush, more new world, CA profile; GV-89+
