When the village of Ebenezer was founded in 1851 in the northern part of the Barossa Valley, vineyards were planted immediately thereafter. Though none of the original vines survived, Barossa Valley's 'Ebenezer' Cabernet Sauvignon is grown on this land from vines up to 40 years of age. Winemaker Stuart Bourne crafts this not-to-be-missed wine in an elegant style with great depth of flavour. This rich and weighty Cabernet would be delicious served with rare roast beef, but it will also reward 5 to 7 years cellaring.
"Cellar up to 10 Years" - winery recommendation

"A very pale yellow - almost colourless at present. The nose is just full of clean, clear tropical fruit salad aromas. The palate is impeccabley clean and zippy, with tropical fruit right through it, though this years version has a bit more mid palate fuit sweetness and body, which fills it out some. Very good overall, and again, give it a few years in the cellar to see what eventuates.
Polished, generous and powerful, a racy mouthful of blackberry, licorice, plum and pepper flavors that zoom through the finish. Tannins are almost an afterthought. Designed to deepen with cellaring.

Wine: The Y Series - South Australia Riesling
Notes: Bright and juicy, a tangy Riesling with lively green apple, citrus and guava aromas and flavors, echoing nicely on the dry finish. Drink now through 2005. 800 cases imported.   (Source:  Wine Spectator, May 15, 2003).  Jancis Robinson MW says, I suspect that Riesling will worm its way into the affections of a new generation of wine drinkers, not in German but in Australian form; dry and powerful rather than featherlight and fruity. Yalumba Y Series is one of my favourite Australian Rieslings.  Tasting note: Light to medium yellow-green; a full aromatic bouquet with a mix of lime and tropical fruit; the palate is likewise driven by generous, ripe fruit; ready to roll right now. Score - 89. (James Halliday, www.winepros.com.au, Nov. 16, 2002)  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).

The brilliant 2000 d'Arry's Original, a Chateauneuf du Pape look-alike from southern Australia, is a 50-50 blend of Shiraz and Grenache. With lofty alcohol (14.5%), it is a succulent, jammy effort displaying oodles of kirsch liqueur-flavored fruit intermixed with pepper, plum, and spice box characteristics. Heady, rich, and medium to full-bodied, it is a hedonistic, sexy red to enjoy over the next 5-7 years.

The big, dense ruby/purple-colored 2000 The Footbolt Shiraz possesses plenty of camphor-infused blackberry fruit along with underbrush, licorice, and earth notes. As with most of the d'Arenberg reds, the oak is kept well in the background. With medium to full body, and excellent texture as well as richness, this 2000 Shiraz will drink well for 5-7 years.

RP: "The 1998 The Dead Arm Shiraz (from a vineyard planted prior to 1890) is outrageously rich, spectacular stuff, the likes of which only Australia seems capable of making. Whiners may complain that it is too big, too rich, too flavorful, and too damn good, but this opaque purple-colored offering is loaded with blackberry liqueur, smoke, charcoal, pepper, cassis, and licorice. Unctuously-textured and full-bodied, but neither heavy nor overbearing, the wine's sweet tannin and low acidity are hidden in the cascade of fruit and glycerin that melt on the palate. This riveting, compelling effort can be drunk now, but promises to age well for two decades or more."

Firm in texture, with juicy blackberry and pepper flavors. Reminiscent of Shiraz, except for the lighter texture. Drink now through 2003. 10,000 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, May 31, 2002).  Francis and Chester Osborn, featured in our spotlight 'Princes of Dark Wine' in April 2003, return with their grand interpretation of Grenache. This is a repurchase of the same vintage we last released in September 2002.  Tasting note: Appearance: ruby. Nose: cedar, white pepper, alcoholic. Taste: sweet raspberry, jammy, well integrated note, full on the palate. Score - **** (out of 5). (Tony Aspler, www.tonyaspler.com, Aug. 15, 2002)  Food match: roast pheasant or other game birds.

Tasting note: This wine, one of two of the flagship Normans' wines, was made at Norman's Clarendon Winery with fruit sourced from old, low-yielding vines from both McLaren Vale and Barossa. It's a big brooding 'mother' with a bouquet dominated by sweet, rich licorice, blackberry and cherry aromas plus whiffs of French ... oak. This intensity carries through to the palate with sweet, mouth filling fruit and layers of choc-mint, coconut and aniseed culminating in a lip smacking long finish. Sure you can drink it now, but three to five years in the cellar will reward the prudent. (www.food-fun-wine.com.au, Jan. 2003)  Food match: rich beef stew, osso bucco.  (Source:  Vintages, April 5, 2003)

Medium red-purple; the moderately intense bouquet has a mix of typically earthy/savoury aromas and red fruits at the centre. The palate is soft and quite supple, again showing savoury/briary characters, finishing with fine tannins.  (Source:  winepros.com, James Halliday, November 22, 2002)

Medium red, with some purple hues remaining; the moderately intense bouquet has a range of savoury/earthy/secondary aromas; there is good depth to the fruit on the palate in a black/dark berry spectrum plus a distinct touch of chocolate. Good tannin balance. Best 2003-2013. Enjoy with strong mature cheddar or stilton. Score - 89. (James Halliday, www.winepros.com.au, Oct. 16, 2001).  Comments on the estate:  Beautiful historic family estate.  Reds for long ageing, also Riesling and Marsanne.

Our panel's tasting note: Deep ruby colour with aromas of cassis, walnut shell and raspberry. Very Claret in style. Quite dry, very well-structured with good grip for some mid-term ageing (4+ years). Medium full-bodied with a long finish.  Food match: roast leg of lamb with rosemary and garlic.  (Source:  Vintages, May 2003).

The Riddoch red wines from Katnook Estate, in the heart of Coonawarra, consistently deliver full flavour, solidity, substance and satisfaction. So it is again with the latest Cabernet/Shiraz. Perhaps it will mellow out into an even more interesting creature over the next five years and hold its form for up to a decade, but I would be more than happy to enjoy this one now with hearty winter foods. Score - **** (out of 5). (Paddy Kendler, The Herald Sun, 'The Quaffing Guide', July 23, 2002)
will age well up to 25 yrs

Deep ruby, almost black in colour with aromas of pepper, blackberry, smoked meat and leather. Dry, youthful tannins, ripe fruit beneath. Needs 4+ years to really come together. (David Churchill, Vintages, July 2003).  (Source:  Vintages, September 2003).  Another of the more impressive reds in today's release comes, not surprisingly, from the same winery. Cape Mentelle Shiraz 2001 ($24.95, No. 452516) borders on the bold, with big flavours of prune, cherry and violet, yet there's a Rhone-like firmness, spice and gamey quality here uncharacteristic of Australia's more classic McLaren Vale shirazes.  (Source:  Beppi Crosariol, Globe and Mail, September 6, 2003).

Tasting note: A fifty/fifty blend of the two varieties which is partially barrel-fermented, and is one of the most reliable examples, year-in, year-out. The complex herb and spice fruit of the bouquet is followed by intense and powerful flavours of herb, citrus and gooseberry, the oak subtle throughout. Gold plated. (James Halliday, www.winepros.com.au, Oct. 16, 2002)

Spicy, white pepper, gamey, cassis, blackberry and leather aromas. Look for smoky, pepper, leather cassis jam and boysenberry flavours in a supple easy-to-sip package. The finish is blend of fresh coffee and vanilla notes. A bit dry and young but it should open over the next year to reveal plenty of fruit.

Though new to our market, Capel Vale Wines was established in 1980. Winepros.com.au writes that this wine is certainly one of the better unwooded Chardonnays on the market.  Our panel's tasting note: Medium straw colour with aromas of apple and citrus. Dry, zesty/lively and fresh. Medium full-bodied with a surprisingly long finish. (Nov. 2002).  Food match: salmon terrine.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).

Region: Australia - New South Wales - Hunter Valley
Notes: 'Heritage Road' came by its name because of politics. It was originally named 'Hermitage Road' (the winery, on the label, still bears that name) after the location of the property. Starting with the 1999 vintage, the 'm' was dropped, changing the name to Heritage because of an agreement Australia has with France. Under this agreement Australia may not name any of their wines or wineries after appellation contrôlée names found in France. Hermitage, of course, is a famous region in the Northern Rhône. Similarly, Penfolds dropped Hermitage from Grange Hermitage. Founded in 1997 by Lisa McGuigan, daughter of Brian McGuigan, the winery is known as Tempus Two in Oz. The wines are made by New Zealand expat Peter Hall. He worked at several Australian properties before joining the winery in 1996. This is one of three Reserve wines we are releasing on September 20th. The other two are Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon and Reserve Shiraz (905976 and 905968 respectively). Each is single vineyard designated and made in small lots by Hall because, as a winemaker, he has always been intrigued by what an individual property can bring to a wine. The Shiraz is from Limestone Coast and the Cabernet is from Barossa Valley.  (Source:  Vintages, September 6, 2003).

This is a repurchase of the same vintage we last released in September 2002.  Tasting note: Deep red-purple; clean, rich savoury, chocolate, plum and berry fruit on the bouquet leads into a medium-bodied palate which flows well across the tongue, the flavours tracking the bouquet. Excellent for the vintage. Score - 90. (James Halliday, www.winepros.com.au, Jan. 31, 2002)  Food match: filet mignon.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).
Jack collection

The Muscadelle (Tokay) exhibits a light amber color as well as a gorgeous fragrance, and plenty of honey and molasses characteristics in a full-bodied, unctuous style. This is a real value. This singular treasure from Australia should not be missed! Score - 92. (Robert Parker Jr., www.erobertparker.com, Aug. 2003).  Food match: pecan pie.  Amber in color, lightly fortified, syrupy sweet and rich with almond, dried apricot, orange peel, coffee and clove flavors, which mingle seductively on the long finish. Drink now. 2,000 cases imported. (Wine Spectator, July 31, 2003)

Grape Tray: Using grapes from its vineyards in Margaret River and Great Southern, Howard Park achieves a true Burgundian character.  This wine strives for elegance and shows its potential with beautiful honeyed, hazelnut overtones that come to the fore as the flavors linger on and on.  At first it seems relatively modest, but then the finish kicks in and whoo-ee.

Wine: Dennis  McLaren Vale Old Tawny Port
Peter Dennis McLaren Vale Unwooded Charonnay

Notes: Decade Blend - Blend of Reserve for 10 years

Region: Australia - South Australia - Limestone Coast - Wrattonbully
Notes: Pleasant in flavor, with earthy, herbal undertones to the basic apple fruit, finishing lively. Drink now. 1,300 cases imported.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, September 15, 2002)

"The 2002 Shiraz is an elegant yet powerful red aged 22 months in 80% French and 20% American oak barrels. Deep ruby/purple-colored, with full body, and loads of blackberry, cassis, licorice, earth, and vanilla aromas as well as flavors, this chewy Shiraz possesses good underlying acidity along with fine definition and purity. It should drink well for 7-8 years."
gift from Betty

This big, smooth wine is polished, ripe and complex, offering roasted meat and walnut accents to its black cherry, blackberry, tobacco and liquorice aromas and flavours.  Lingers appealingly on the expansive finish.

Deep red with crimson hues, offering a complex bouquet of lifted black cherries and fruitcake with just a hint of barnyard. A silkily textured palate with intense black fruit flavours supported by classy oak, finishing with velvety tannins and long persistence. Score - **** 1/2 (out of 5). (www.winestate.com.au, July/Aug. 2003)
UPC code is 13 digits:  9329541005536; 14% alc.;
CabS 52%, Shiraz 33%, Dolcetto 10%, Grenache 5%

This 100% Shiraz from both the Eden and Barossa Valleys was aged 24 months in small French and American foudres. A dense purple color is followed by gorgeous aromas of creme de cassis, and full-bodied, full-throttle, well-balanced blackberry and currant flavors intermixed with licorice, tar, and pepper. Consume it during its first 7-8 years of life.
Australia Trip

A 100 percent Shiraz blended from low-yielding vineyards; a big wine with an extraordinary sense of elegance. It positively glows with gorgeous blueberry, plum and white pepper flavors that skim across the palate like a sailboat in a perfect wind. Hints of mineral and spice weave through the long, long finish. Classic stuff
Grenache 60%; Mataro 20%; Shiraz 20%
The Brown's

The 2007 Cat Amongst The Pigeons Nine Lives Shiraz The red wine lineup begins with the 2007 Shiraz. Opaque purple-colored, it has an enticing perfume of spice box, blue fruits, and smoked meat. This leads to a savory, ripe, full-flavored wine with layered fruit, excellent balance, and a lengthy close. Drink it over the next four years.  (Dr Jay Miller - Wine Advocate 91/100)
Firm in texture, with a solid core of dark berry and currant flavors, shaded with smoky, slightly tarry notes that mingle through the cocoa-scented finish. 5,625 cases made

"Kaesler's winemaker, Reid Bosward, is a consulting winemaker for David Knight, and together they have created one of the world's great dry red wine bargains. Aged ten months in neutral French wood, this 100% Shiraz tips the scales at 15.5% alcohol. It is a sexy, delicious 'winner' boasting amazing opulence, purity, and richness. A true southern Australian fruit bomb - and proud of it, it is the kind of wine that simply does not exist anywhere else in the world. Enjoy it over the next 3-4 years." #3; COLOR-dark purple, black; NOSE-lot of fruit, bacon fat, dark blackberry, plum, black currant; hint of a rounded citrus aspect (orange peel, mango, apricot); TASTE-if you're a fan of over-the-top extracted Shiraz's (Mollydooker, Schild etc.) you will like this; not quite as refined, but tons of fruit, dark chocolate, creme de cassis, little off balance & very young, very delicious, syrupy; RP-91; GV-89
Potential Classic
Drink young
Drink young
Excellent wine
tropical aromas fresh gooseberry notes and flinty steely characters

Though New Zealand has long been known for its Sauvignon Blancs, Pinot Gris is starting to emerge as an equally strong grape variety for the country. As they did with Sauvignon Blanc, New Zealand producers are developing their own, unique take on Pinot Gris.  Our panel's tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of hawthorn, peach, apple, hay and spice. Dry, soft centred, much more characterful than many Oregonian examples. Medium-bodied with a lingering finish. (Oct. 2002)  Food match: sushi, teriyaki chicken.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).

Tasting note: Light to medium straw-green; the moderately intense bouquet has a mix of mineral, herb and passionfruit, the palate with passionfruit, pear, apple and mineral notes running through to a dry finish. Excellent value. Enjoy with vegetable terrine. Score - 89. (James Halliday, www.winespro.com.au, Sept. 6, 2002)
Drink young

Collards' flagship wine ... With the crop only 20% of average because of a frost at flowering, the resulting low yields have produced a particularly elegant, tightly structured chardonnay. (www.caros.co.nz)  Our panel's tasting note: Aromas suggest apricot, banana, anise, buttery toast and charred oak. Dry and full-bodied with a firm finish. (Oct. 2002)  Food match: smoked fish.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).

Winepros.com.au describes Collards as a family-owned and run business which is a bastion of conservatism, adopting a low promotional profile, but which consistently produces fastidiously crafted wines of excellent quality, and which has moved with the times in developing new wines and labels. Run by brothers Bruce and Geoff Collard, the winery stopped producing Gewurztraminer in 1990, but has returned with this 2002.  Our panel's tasting note: Aromas of mandarin oranges, lychee, nutmeg and spices. Dry, silky and fruity on the palate. (Nov. 2002)  Food match: spiced pork dishes.  (Source:  Vintages, July 2003).
Excellent wine
Old Doc's;

The 2004 is the finest for several years. Deliciously weighty, lively and rich ? it has concentrated, sweet fruit characters and fresh, vibrant melon, passionfruit and lime flavours showing lovely depth.
ripe tropical aromas and flavours
"Highly recommended:  good, all-round solid chard, crisp acidity, good fruit, not too much oak (Source:  Natalie Maclean web site:

Bright, vivid, aromatic Sauvignon Blanc, fragrant with lime and passion fruit, leaning toward mineral notes as the flavors linger on the zingy finish. Drink now. 13,000 cases made. (Source:  Wine Spectator, December 15, 2002)
Drink Youngish
Juicy, tangy style drips with citrus, passion fruit and mineral flavors that linger impressively on the finish. Drink now. 1,000 cases imported. (Source:  Wine Spectator, November 15, 2002).
Classic wine rated. 14.5%. Toast/butterscotch aroma, grape/peach fruit characters, toast oak.
iconic New Zealand wine

In 1993, after sailing all over the world for 6 years, John and Jennifer Joslin purchased 20 acres (8 ha) of land in the legendary Marlborough region. The vineyard is called 'LeGrys', after Jennifer Joslin's maiden name. Like many of the top New Zealand wine producers, Mud House uses a Stelvin cap closure on their Sauvignon Blanc and Riesling to avoid troublesome cork taint. To add a layer of complexity to the wines, a small amount was aged in French oak. A portion of those oaked wines also underwent the acid-softening process of malolactic fermentation.  Our panel's tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of gooseberry, fresh herbs, hawthorn, guava and passion fruit. Dry, crisp and clean with good aroma replays. Balanced and nicely structured. Medium full-bodied with a lingering crisp/fruit finish. (Sept. 2002)  Food match: asparagus and stir-fried shrimp.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Comments on 2001 vintage:  Bright and zippy, balancing its pear, grapefruit and apricot flavors enticingly against a sharp edge of lemony acidity. Delicious and invigorating. Drink now.4,000 cases made.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, July 31, 2002).

Red Birch is a joint venture between John and Brigid Forrest of Forrest Estate Wines and Terry and Lynley Sowman of Sowman Estate. The 2001 vintage won a Gold Medal at the 2002 InterVin International Wine Competition in Ontario.  Our panel's tasting note: Pale straw colour with aromas of lime zest, gooseberry, passion fruit and tamarind. Dry, pretty wine with good balance between the fruit and the acid. Light to medium-bodied with a solid finish. An excellent apéritif wine. (Dec. 2002)  Food match: chicken, snow pea and shiitake mushroom stir-fry.  (Source:  Vintages, June 2003).  Comments on 2000 vintage:  Bright and refreshing, with lime, Bosc pear and mineral flavors that echo nicely on the finish. 3,000 cases made.  (Wine Spectator, September 15, 2001).

Bright and juicy, with racy herbal notes weaving through the ripe melon and tropical fruit flavors, which echo on the round finish. Drink now. 7,000 cases imported.  Rated 'Smart Buy'.  (Source:  Wine Spectator, November 15, 2002).

Thornbury is a newcomer to the winemaking scene, having been established in 1998. The winemaker/partner is Steve Bird, former Morton Estate winemaker. Currently, they make only three wines: this Chardonnay, a Merlot and a Sauvignon Blanc. The winery is located in Hawkes Bay. The Chardonnay and Merlot are from their vineyards there; the Sauvignon Blanc is from Marlborough.  Food match: smoked salmon risotto.  (Source:  Vintages, May 10, 2003).  Beautifully silky and rich in texture, showing remarkable restraint on the flavour profile, offering earthy, slightly gamey grace notes to a vibrant core of pear and mineral flavours. Drink now through 2005. (Source:  Wine Spectator, May 31, 2002)
